section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: ï¿½Consummationï¿½ means the time at which a customer becomes contractually obligated under a lease agreement with an option to purchase. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Customerï¿½ means a natural person who leases personal property which is to be used primarily for personal, family or household purposes pursuant to a lease agreement with an option to purchase. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Lease agreement with an option to purchaseï¿½ means an agreement: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the possession and use of personal property by a natural person primarily for personal, family or household purposes, for an initial period of not more than 4 months; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
That does not obligate or require the customer to continue leasing or using the property beyond the initial period; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
That permits the customer to acquire the ownership of the property. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Lessorï¿½ means a person who regularly provides the possession and use of property pursuant to a lease agreement with an option to purchase and to whom rental payments are initially payable as indicated on the face of the agreement.

section.heading: Applicability of laws.

content.p: A lease agreement with an option to purchase which complies with the provisions ofNRS 597.010to597.110, inclusive, is exempt from the provisions of law governing: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A security interest as defined inNRS 104.1201. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A door-to-door sale as defined inNRS 598.180. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The sale of consumer goods as defined inNRS 104.9102. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions ofNRS 597.010to597.110, inclusive, do not apply to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A lease agreement with an option to purchase entered into primarily for business, commercial or agricultural purposes. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A lease agreement with an option to purchase made with any governmental agency. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The lease of a safe deposit box. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A lease or bailment of personal property which is incidental to the lease of real property and which does not provide the customer with an option to purchase the leased property. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The lease of a motor vehicle.

section.heading: Lease agreement: Disclosures required; exception to requirement; provision of copy to customer.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, a lease agreement with an option to purchase must contain the following disclosures, if applicable: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The total number and total amount of all payments which are necessary to acquire ownership of the leased property, and the dates on which those payments are due. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A statement that the customer will not own the leased property until he or she makes all of the payments necessary to acquire ownership. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A statement that the customer is responsible for the fair market value of the leased property if it is lost, stolen, damaged or destroyed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A brief description of the leased property which is sufficient to identify the property to the customer and lessor, including: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The identification number of the property, if available; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A statement indicating whether the property is new or used. It is not a violation of this section to indicate that new property is used. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A brief description of any damage to the leased property. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A statement of the price at which the lessor will sell the leased property to the customer for cash on the date of the agreement. If at least five items are leased as a set in a single agreement, the aggregate price of all of the items leased may be indicated. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The total amount of the payments required to be paid at or before the consummation of the agreement or the delivery of the leased property, whichever is later. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A statement that the total amount of all payments required to be paid does not include other fees which may be charged. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A statement of all other fees which may be charged, including, but not limited to, fees for: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The failure to make timely payments. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Defaulting on the agreement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Reinstating the agreement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Returning the leased property to the lessor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A summary of the terms of the customerï¿½s option to purchase the leased property, including a statement that the customer has the right to purchase the leased property at any time before the termination of the lease, and the price at which the property may be so purchased. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A statement identifying the person who is responsible for maintaining and servicing the property while it is being leased, and a description of that responsibility. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A statement that if any part of the manufacturerï¿½s express warranty covers the leased property when the customer acquires ownership of the property, it will be transferred to the customer if allowed by the terms of the warranty. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The date of the transaction and the names of the customer and lessor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A statement that the customer may terminate the agreement without penalty by voluntarily surrendering or returning the leased property in good repair at the expiration of the term of the lease, and paying any rental payments that are past due. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A notice of the customerï¿½s right to reinstate the agreement pursuant toNRS 597.070. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A lessor is not required to comply with the provisions of this section if the transaction is governed by Part E of the Consumer Credit Protection Act, 15 U.S.C. ï¿½ï¿½ 1667 to 1667e, inclusive, and the lessor complies with the requirements of those sections and the regulations adopted pursuant thereto. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The lessor shall provide the customer with a copy of the lease agreement with an option to purchase.

section.heading: Required disclosures: Manner of making; transactions with multiple lessors; effect of inaccuracy caused by customer.

content.p: The disclosures required to be made byNRS 597.030must be made: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
At or before the consummation of the lease agreement with an option to purchase; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Clearly and conspicuously in writing on the face of the agreement, directly above the line for the customerï¿½s signature. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In a transaction involving more than one lessor, only one lessor is required to make the required disclosures, but all lessors are bound by those disclosures. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a disclosure becomes inaccurate after it is delivered to the customer because of an act or omission of the customer, the resulting inaccuracy is not a violation of the provisions ofNRS 597.010to597.110, inclusive.

section.heading: Lease agreement: Disclosures required upon renegotiation but not upon extension; when deemed to be renegotiated.

content.p: The disclosures required byNRS 597.030: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Must be made if a lease agreement with an option to purchase is renegotiated. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Are not required to be made if such an agreement is extended. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the purposes of this section, a lease agreement with an option to purchase: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is renegotiated if it is replaced by a new agreement entered into by the same customer and lessor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has not been renegotiated if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The leased property is exchanged or added to or individual items are returned and the average payment is not changed by more than 25 percent; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any additional fees charged are reduced; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
It is the subject of a judicial proceeding.

section.heading: Lease agreement: Prohibited provisions.

content.p: A confession of judgment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A negotiable instrument. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A security interest or any other claim to an interest in property other than the property delivered by the lessor pursuant to the agreement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An assignment of wages. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A waiver by the customer of any claims or defenses. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A provision authorizing the lessor, or any other person acting on his or her behalf, to commit any breach of the peace, in order to repossess the leased property.

section.heading: Lease agreement: Reinstatement after customer fails to make timely payment.

content.p: A customer who fails to make a timely payment may reinstate the lease agreement with an option to purchase without losing any rights or options contained in the agreement if the customer pays to the lessor: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
All payments that are past due; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The reasonable costs of returning the property to the lessor and redelivering it to the customer, if the leased property has been returned to the lessor; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any applicable fee for making a late payment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The payments required to be made by subsection 1 must be made within: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Five days after the date for renewing the agreement if the customerï¿½s payments are required to be made monthly; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Two days after the date for renewing the agreement if the customerï¿½s payments are required to be made more frequently. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a customer has paid less than two-thirds of the total amount of the payments necessary to acquire ownership of the leased property and, during the time set forth in subsection 2, returns or voluntarily surrenders the property to the lessor, other than pursuant to a judicial order, the customer may reinstate the agreement within 21 days after the date on which the property was returned. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a customer has paid at least two-thirds of the total amount of the payments necessary to acquire ownership of the leased property and, during the time set forth in subsection 2, returns or voluntarily surrenders the property to the lessor, other than pursuant to a judicial order, the customer may reinstate the agreement within 45 days after the date on which the property was returned. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

This section does not prohibit a lessor from repossessing the leased property during the time allowed for reinstatement. If the lessor repossesses the leased property during that time: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The repossession does not affect the customerï¿½s right to reinstate the agreement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The lessor shall return the property to the customer or provide the customer with property which is of comparable quality and in comparable condition if the agreement is reinstated.

section.heading: Receipt required for certain payments by customer.

content.p: A lessor shall give to a customer a written receipt for each payment made in cash or with a money order.

section.heading: Advertisement for lease agreement that refers to payment or right to acquire ownership: Requirements; exception; liability.

content.p: An advertisement for a lease agreement with an option to purchase that refers to or states the amount of any required payment and the right to acquire ownership of any individual item of property must clearly and conspicuously indicate: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The total amount of payments necessary to acquire ownership of the property; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
That the customer does not acquire ownership of the property if the total amount of payments is not paid. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section does not apply to an advertisement for a lease agreement with an option to purchase which is published in a telephone or business directory. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

This section does not create any liability for the acts of a publisher, owner, agent or employee of a newspaper, magazine, periodical, radio station, television station or other advertising medium for the publication or dissemination of an advertisement for a lease agreement with an option to purchase if the publisher, owner, agent or employee did not know that the advertisement violated the provisions of this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

As used in this section, ï¿½advertisementï¿½ means the attempt by publication, dissemination, solicitation or circulation to induce, directly or indirectly, any person to enter into a lease agreement with an option to purchase.

section.heading: Criminal penalty.

content.p: A person who willfully and intentionally violates any provision ofNRS 597.010to597.090, inclusive, is guilty of a misdemeanor.

section.heading: Civil penalty.

content.p: In addition to any penalty imposed pursuant toNRS 597.100, the lessor or his or her assignee is liable, except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, in civil suit to the customer for an amount equal to the actual damages resulting from a violation of a provision ofNRS 597.010to597.110, inclusive, or 25 percent of the total cost to acquire ownership of the property under the lease agreement, whichever amount is greater. The court shall award the prevailing party in such an action attorneyï¿½s fees and his or her costs of the action. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the lessor commences a civil suit to enforce such a lease agreement, the customer may set off or counterclaim damages in the amount specified in subsection 1 for such a violation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Such a civil penalty may not be imposed upon a lessor or his or her assignee unless: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The customer has notified the lessor or, if applicable, his or her assignee in writing of the alleged violation; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The lessor or assignee does not correct the violation, if any, within 30 days after receiving the notice.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: As used inNRS 597.112to597.118, inclusive, unless the context otherwise requires, the words and terms defined inNRS 597.1123to597.114, inclusive, have the meanings ascribed to them in those sections.

section.heading: Dealerï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Dealerï¿½ means any person who engages in the business of selling inventory.

section.heading: ï¿½Dealer agreementï¿½ defined.

content.p: The dealer constitutes a component of a system for the distribution of inventory; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The operation of a portion of the dealerï¿½s business is substantially dependent upon the supplier for a continued supply of inventory.

section.heading: ï¿½Inventoryï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Inventoryï¿½ means farm equipment or any attachments or repair parts for that farm equipment.

section.heading: Net priceï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Net priceï¿½ means the price set forth in the price list or catalog of a supplier which is in effect when a dealer agreement is terminated, less any applicable trade or cash discounts.

section.heading: Superseded partï¿½ and ï¿½superseded repair partï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Superseded partï¿½ or ï¿½superseded repair partï¿½ means a part which has an equivalent function of a part which is available on the date of the termination of a dealer agreement.

section.heading: Supplierï¿½ defined.

content.p: A purchaser of the assets or shares of a surviving corporation resulting from a merger or liquidation of a supplier; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A receiver, assignee or trustee of such a manufacturer, wholesaler or wholesale distributor.

section.heading: Dealer agreement: Termination, failure to renew or substantial change of terms for good cause.

content.p: A supplier shall not terminate, fail to renew or substantially change the terms of a dealer agreement without good cause. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in this section, a supplier may terminate or refuse to renew a dealer agreement for good cause if the supplier provides to the dealer a written notice setting forth the reasons for the termination or nonrenewal of the dealer agreement at least 180 days before the termination or nonrenewal of the dealer agreement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A supplier shall include in the written notice required by subsection 2 an explanation of the deficiencies of the dealer and the manner in which those deficiencies must be corrected. If the dealer corrects the deficiencies set forth in the notice within 60 days after he or she receives the notice, the supplier shall not terminate or fail to renew the dealer agreement for the reasons set forth in the notice. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A supplier shall not terminate or refuse to renew a dealer agreement based solely on the failure of the dealer to comply with the requirements of the dealer agreement concerning the share of the market the dealer was required to obtain unless the supplier has, for not less than 1 year, provided assistance to the dealer in the dealerï¿½s effort to obtain the required share of the market. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A supplier is not required to comply with the provisions of subsections 2 and 3 if the supplier terminates or refuses to renew a dealer agreement for any reason set forth in paragraphs
to
, inclusive, of subsection 6. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½good causeï¿½ means: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A dealer fails to comply with the terms of a dealer agreement, if the terms are not substantially different from the terms required for other dealers in this State or any other state; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A closeout or sale of a substantial part of the business assets of a dealer or a commencement of the dissolution or liquidation of the business assets of the dealer; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A dealer changes its principal place of business or adds other places of business without the prior approval of the supplier, which may not be unreasonably withheld; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A dealer substantially defaults under a chattel mortgage or other security agreement between the dealer and the supplier; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A dealer abandons the dealership; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A dealer pleads guilty or guilty but mentally ill to, or is convicted of, a felony affecting the business relationship between the dealer and supplier; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A dealer transfers a financial interest in the dealership, a person who has a substantial financial interest in the ownership or control of the dealership dies or withdraws from the dealership, or the financial interest of a partner or major shareholder in the dealership is substantially reduced. ï¿½For the purposes of this section, good cause does not exist if the supplier consents to any action described in this section.

section.heading: Return of surplus parts to supplier; credit for returned parts.

content.p: Each year a supplier shall allow each dealer with whom it has entered into a dealer agreement to return to the supplier for credit a portion of the surplus parts in the dealerï¿½s inventory. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A supplier shall notify each dealer of the period it has designated for that dealer to submit a list of the surplus parts the dealer wishes to return and for that dealer to return the surplus parts to the supplier. The period designated for each dealer for the return of surplus parts must not be less than 90 days. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a supplier fails to notify a dealer of the period during which the dealer may return surplus parts within the preceding 12 months, the supplier shall authorize the return of a dealerï¿½s surplus parts within 60 days after the supplier receives a request from the dealer to return the surplus parts. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A dealer may return surplus parts equal to not more than 10 percent of the value of the parts purchased by the dealer from the supplier during: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The 12-month period immediately preceding the notice provided to the dealer by the supplier pursuant to subsection 2; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The month the supplier receives a request from a dealer pursuant to subsection 3 to return surplus parts to the supplier, ï¿½whichever is applicable. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any part included in the supplierï¿½s list of returnable parts or any superseded part that is not eligible for return to the supplier on the date the supplier provides notice to the dealer pursuant to subsection 2 or the date the supplier receives the dealerï¿½s request pursuant to subsection 3, whichever is applicable, is eligible for credit as a returned surplus part. A part which is returned must be in new and undamaged condition and must have been purchased by the dealer from the supplier to whom it is returned. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The minimum credit allowed for a returned part is 95 percent of the net price, as set forth in the supplierï¿½s list of returnable parts on the date the supplier provides notice to the dealer pursuant to subsection 2 or the date the supplier receives the dealerï¿½s request pursuant to subsection 3, whichever is applicable. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
All applicable credit for the returned parts must be issued or provided to the dealer within 90 days after the supplier receives the dealerï¿½s returned surplus parts. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Do not apply to a supplier that has established a program for its dealers for the return of surplus repair parts if the program provides credit of not less than 85 percent of the net price for the returned repair parts; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Do not prohibit a supplier from charging a dealerï¿½s account for the amounts previously paid or credited by the supplier as a discount incident to the dealerï¿½s purchase of goods; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Do not require a dealer to return for credit surplus parts to a supplier.

section.heading: Limitations on requirements imposed by supplier upon dealer; prohibition against certain changes to dealer agreement.

content.p: Require a dealer to accept delivery of equipment, parts or accessories which the dealer has not ordered unless the equipment, parts or accessories are required by the supplier for the safe use of any inventory provided to the dealer by the supplier; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Condition the sale of any equipment to a dealer upon the purchase of additional goods or services, except that a supplier may require a dealer to purchase those parts which are necessary to maintain the equipment used in the area where the dealership is located; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Prohibit a dealer from purchasing equipment manufactured by another supplier; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Terminate, fail to renew or substantially change the terms of a dealer agreement because of a natural disaster, including a drought in the market area of the dealership, a labor dispute or any other similar circumstances which are beyond the control of the dealer.

section.heading: Repurchase of inventory and equipment by supplier upon termination of dealer agreement.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in this section, upon the termination of a dealer agreement by a supplier or dealer, the supplier shall repurchase the inventory held by the dealer on the date of the termination of the dealer agreement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A supplier who repurchases the inventory of a dealer pursuant to subsection 1 shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Pay the dealer: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
One hundred percent of the net price of all new and undamaged inventory; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Ninety-five percent of the net price of new and undamaged superseded repair parts. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in this paragraph, pay the dealer an amount equal to 5 percent of the net price of all new and undamaged repair parts returned to the supplier to cover the cost incurred by the dealer for handling, packing and shipping the superseded repair parts to the supplier. If the supplier handles, packs and ships the superseded repair parts, the dealer is not entitled to receive any money for those services which the supplier performed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Purchase, at its depreciated value, any computers, software or telecommunications equipment that the supplier required the dealer to purchase within the previous 5 years. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Repurchase, at 75 percent of the net cost, any specialized repair tools purchased if those tools are: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Held by the dealer on the date of the termination of the dealer agreement; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Complete and in resalable condition. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Repurchase any inventory which is owned by the supplier and leased, rented or used in demonstrations by the dealer if the supplier receives an allowance based on the use of such inventory. Inventory which is used in demonstrations for not more than a total of 50 hours shall be deemed new inventory. Inventory which is used in demonstrations for more than 50 hours and purchased from the supplier less than 36 months before the termination of the dealerï¿½s agreement must be repurchased at its depreciated value, as determined by the supplier and dealer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the dealer agreement authorizes the dealer to retain the inventory upon the termination of the dealer agreement, the dealer may retain any portion of the inventory, except any specialized tools described in paragraph
of subsection 2 which the supplier wishes to repurchase from the dealer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the dealer owes any outstanding debts to the supplier, the amount of the repurchase of the inventory may be set off or credited to the account of the dealer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Upon payment to the dealer of the amount for the repurchase of the inventory pursuant to this section, the title and right of possession to the inventory transfers to the supplier.

section.heading: Requirements regarding dealerï¿½s reserve account for recourse after termination of dealer agreement.

content.p: At the end of each year after the termination of a dealer agreement, a dealerï¿½s reserve account for recourse, retail sale or lease contracts may not be debited by a supplier or lender for any deficiency unless the dealer is given written notice of at least 7 business days by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, of any proposed sale of the inventory which was financed and an opportunity to purchase the inventory. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The dealer must be given quarterly reports concerning any remaining outstanding recourse contracts. As the recourse contracts are reduced, any money in the reserve account must be returned to the dealer in direct proportion to the liabilities outstanding.

section.heading: Limitations on requirements for supplier to repurchase inventory.

content.p: Any repair part which is not in new and undamaged condition or, because of its condition, is not resalable as a new part; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any inventory which was ordered by the dealer on or after the date of the termination of the dealer agreement; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any inventory which was purchased more than 36 months before the notice of the termination of the dealer agreement is provided.

section.heading: Failure of supplier to repurchase inventory.

content.p: Attorneyï¿½s fees and court costs; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An amount equal to the interest on the amount of the net price calculated at the legal rate of interest from the 61st day after the date of the shipment of the inventory to the supplier.

section.heading: Death of dealer or majority shareholder of dealer.

content.p: Upon the death of a dealer or the majority shareholder of a corporation which operates as a dealer, the supplier shall, upon the approval or request of the devisee or heir of the dealer or majority shareholder, repurchase the inventory of the dealer in the manner prescribed inNRS 597.1153. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The devisee or heir shall, within 1 year after the death of the dealer or majority stockholder, notify the supplier whether the supplier will be required to repurchase the inventory of the dealer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A supplier is not required to repurchase the inventory of the dealer if the devisee or heir and the supplier enter into a new dealer agreement to operate the dealership. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section does not authorize any person, including a devisee or heir, to operate a dealership without the written approval of the supplier. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An agreement executed by the supplier and dealer that sets forth the rights relating to succession to the operation of the dealership is enforceable without regard to the person who is designated as the successor to the dealership. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Deviseeï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 132.100. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Heirï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 132.165.

section.heading: Security interest of supplier in inventory; inspection of inventory before shipment.

content.p: The provisions ofNRS 597.112to597.118, inclusive, do not affect any security interest which a supplier has in the inventory of a dealer. The dealer and supplier shall each provide a representative to inspect the inventory and certify its acceptability when packaged for shipment. The failure of the supplier to provide a representative for the inspection within 60 days shall be deemed acceptance by the supplier of the inventory returned to the supplier.

section.heading: Enforcement by dealer.

content.p: A dealer may bring a civil action for damages in a court of competent jurisdiction against a supplier who violates any of the provisions ofNRS 597.112to597.118, inclusive, and may recover damages incurred as a result of any violation committed by the supplier, including costs and attorneyï¿½s fees. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A dealer may apply for injunctive relief for the unlawful termination, nonrenewal or substantial change of the terms of a dealer agreement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The remedies provided in this section are in addition to any other remedies provided by law.

section.heading: Warranty work performed by dealer; payment of warranty claim by supplier; audit of claim.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in this section, any agreement entered into by a supplier and a dealer concerning reimbursement for work performed under a warranty, including, without limitation, a dealer agreement, must comply with the provisions set forth in this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A supplier who authorizes a dealer to perform work under a warranty shall reimburse a dealer who submits a warranty claim for such work. A dealer may submit a warranty claim to a supplier: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
During the period the dealer agreement is in effect; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
After the termination of a dealer agreement if the warranty claim concerns work performed under a warranty during the period the dealer agreement was in effect. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A warranty claim which is submitted to a supplier must be paid within 30 days after the claim is approved by the supplier. The supplier shall approve or disapprove a warranty claim or any part thereof within 30 days after it receives the warranty claim. If the warranty claim is disapproved, the supplier shall, not later than 30 days after it receives the warranty claim, send written notice to the dealer setting forth the reasons for disapproval of the warranty claim. A warranty claim which is not disapproved by the supplier within the prescribed period shall be deemed approved. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The amount of a warranty claim must not be less than the amount equal to the sum of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The reasonable and customary time required by the dealer to complete the work, including diagnostic time, expressed in hours and fractions of hours, multiplied by the dealerï¿½s hourly retail rate for labor; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The dealerï¿½s net price for any repair parts replaced, plus 20 percent of the net price for those parts; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a warranty claim concerns repair work for any equipment which is performed by the dealer in accordance with a safety or modification order issued by a supplier, the costs incurred by the dealer to transport to the dealerï¿½s place of business for repair any equipment which is within the dealerï¿½s service area and subject to a safety or modification order. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
After a supplier has paid a warranty claim, the supplier shall not charge back, set off or otherwise attempt to recover from a dealer any amount of the warranty claim unless: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The warranty claim is fraudulent; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The work was not performed properly or was not necessary to comply with the requirements of the warranty; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The dealer did not provide the records for the warranty claim as required by the agreement for work performed under the warranty. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A supplier shall not require a dealer to pay the costs incurred by the supplier in paying warranty claims by: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Imposing a surcharge; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Imposing additional requirements for the certification of a dealer authorized to perform work under a warranty. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except for a warranty claim where fraud is alleged, a supplier may not audit the records of a dealer relating to a warranty claim more than 1 year after the warranty claim is submitted to the supplier. A supplier may not audit a warranty claim more than once. The provisions of this subsection do not prohibit a supplier from requesting additional information from a dealer if the initial audit of the warranty claim indicates any errors, inconsistencies or fraud. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The provisions of this section do not apply to a written dealer agreement which provides compensation to a dealer for any labor required to be performed under a warranty before the labor is performed if the compensation is based on: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A reduction of the price of the equipment sold to the dealer; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A lump-sum payment of not less than 5 percent of the suggested retail price of the equipment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Auditï¿½ means an examination by a supplier of the records of a warranty claim submitted by a dealer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Net priceï¿½ means the price a supplier charges a dealer for a repair part. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Warranty claimï¿½ means a request submitted by a dealer to a supplier for payment for work performed under a warranty or a safety or modification order issued by the supplier.

section.heading: Right, obligation or liability may not be waived.

content.p: A person may not waive or modify a right, obligation or liability set forth in the provisions ofNRS 597.112to597.118, inclusive. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A condition, stipulation or provision of a dealer agreement or any other agreement that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Limits the procedural or substantive rights of a dealer pursuant to the provisions ofNRS 597.112to597.118, inclusive; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Requires a person to waive a right set forth in the provisions ofNRS 597.112to597.118, inclusive; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Relieves a person of an obligation or liability imposed by the provisions ofNRS 597.112to597.118, inclusive, ï¿½is void.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: As used inNRS 597.120to597.180, inclusive, unless the context otherwise requires, the words and terms defined inNRS 597.125to597.150, inclusive, have the meanings ascribed to them in those sections.

section.heading: ï¿½Alcoholic beverageï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Alcoholic beverageï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 597.200.

section.heading: ï¿½Franchiseï¿½ defined.

content.p: A commercial relationship of definite duration or continuing indefinite duration is involved; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The wholesaler is granted the right to offer, sell and distribute within this state or any designated area thereof such of the supplierï¿½s brands of packaged malt beverages, distilled spirits and wines, or all of them, as may be specified.

section.heading: ï¿½Good causeï¿½ defined.

content.p: Failure by a wholesaler to comply substantially with essential and reasonable requirements imposed on him or her by a supplier, or sought to be imposed by a supplier, if the requirements are not discriminatory as compared with requirements imposed on other similarly suited wholesalers either by their terms or in the manner of their enforcement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Bad faith by the wholesaler in carrying out the terms of the franchise agreement.

section.heading: ï¿½Marketing areaï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Marketing areaï¿½ means the area where a wholesaler sells a product of a supplier pursuant to the terms, provisions and conditions of a franchise.

section.heading: ï¿½Supplierï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Supplierï¿½ means any person, partnership, corporation or other form of business enterprise engaged in business as a manufacturer, distiller, craft distillery, rectifier, brewer, brew pub, importer, vintner, broker or agent therefor, which distributes any or all of its brands of malt beverages, distilled spirits and wines, or all of them, through licensed wholesalers in this state.

section.heading: ï¿½Wholesalerï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Wholesalerï¿½ means any person, partnership, corporation or other form of business enterprise licensed by the Nevada Tax Commission to sell malt beverages, distilled spirits and wines, or all of them, as it is originally packaged to retail liquor stores or to another licensed wholesaler, or to transfer malt beverages and wine to an estate distillery pursuant toNRS 597.230and597.240, respectively, but not to sell to the consumer or general public.

section.heading: Termination of franchise by supplier: Notice; effective date.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, a supplier must, at least 90 days before he or she terminates or refuses to continue any franchise with a wholesaler or causes a wholesaler to resign from any franchise, send a notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the wholesaler. The notice must include: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The reason for the proposed action and a description of any failure of the wholesaler to comply with the terms, provisions and conditions of the franchise alleged by the supplier pursuant toNRS 597.160; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A statement that the wholesaler may correct any such failure within the period prescribed inNRS 597.160. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any action taken by a supplier pursuant to subsection 1 becomes effective on the date the wholesaler receives the notice required pursuant to subsection 1 if the wholesaler: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has had his or her license to sell alcoholic beverages issued pursuant to state or federal law revoked or suspended for more than 31 days; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is insolvent pursuant to 11 U.S.C. ï¿½ 101; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Or any other person who has a financial interest in the wholesaler of not less than 10 percent and is active in the management of the wholesaler has been convicted of, or has pleaded guilty or guilty but mentally ill to, a felony and the supplier determines that the conviction or plea substantially and adversely affects the ability of the wholesaler to sell the products of the supplier; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has committed fraud or has made a material misrepresentation in his or her dealings with the supplier or the products of the supplier; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has sold alcoholic beverages which the wholesaler received from the supplier to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A retailer who the wholesaler knows or should know does not have a place of business where the retailer is entitled to sell alcoholic beverages within the marketing area of the wholesaler; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any person who the wholesaler knows or should know sells or supplies alcoholic beverages to any retailer who does not have a place of business where the retailer is entitled to sell alcoholic beverages within the marketing area of the wholesaler; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Has failed to pay for any product ordered and delivered pursuant to the provisions of an agreement between the supplier and wholesaler within 7 business days after the supplier sends to the wholesaler a written notice which includes a statement that the wholesaler has failed to pay for the product and a demand for immediate payment; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has made an assignment for the benefit of creditors or a similar disposition of substantially all the assets of his or her franchise; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Or any other person who has a financial interest in the wholesaler has: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Transferred or attempted to transfer the assets of the franchise, voting stock of the wholesaler or voting stock of any parent corporation of the wholesaler; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Changed or attempted to change the beneficial ownership or control of any such entity, ï¿½unless the wholesaler first notified the supplier in writing and the supplier has not unreasonably withheld his or her approval; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Discontinues selling the products of the supplier, unless: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The wholesaler has, if applicable, taken action to correct the condition which caused the accident; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The wholesaler has notified the supplier of the accident if he or she has discontinued selling the products of the supplier for more than 10 days.

section.heading: Transfer of stock or assets or change in ownership or control of wholesaler: Supplier to approve within 60 days if person to be substituted meets certain requirements; supplier shall not unreasonably withhold or delay approval of certain transactions; liability of supplier.

content.p: A supplier shall approve any assignment, sale or transfer of the stock of a wholesaler or of all or any portion of a wholesalerï¿½s assets, a wholesalerï¿½s voting stock, the voting stock of any parent corporation or the beneficial ownership or control of any other entity owning or controlling the wholesaler, including the wholesalerï¿½s rights and obligations under the terms of a franchise, within 60 days after receiving notice of the transaction if the person to be substituted under the terms of the franchise meets reasonable standards imposed upon the wholesaler and any other wholesaler of the supplier of the same general class, after consideration of the size and location of the marketing area of the wholesaler. A supplier shall approve or deny approval of the transaction in writing and, if approval of the transaction is denied, state the material reasons for the denial. If a supplier does not approve or deny approval of the transaction within 60 days after receiving notice of the transaction, the transaction shall be deemed approved. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Upon the death of a partner of a partnership that operates the business of a wholesaler, a supplier shall not unreasonably withhold or delay approval of maintaining the franchise between the supplier and each surviving partner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Upon the death of any owner, controlling shareholder or operator of a wholesaler, a supplier shall not deny approval of any transfer of ownership to a surviving spouse, child or grandchild of the owner who has reached the age of majority at the time of death, controlling shareholder or operator. Any subsequent transfer of ownership by the spouse, child, grandchild, controlling shareholder or operator is subject to the provisions of subsection 1. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In addition to the provisions ofNRS 597.170, a supplier who unreasonably delays or withholds consent or unreasonably denies approval of a sale, transfer or assignment of any ownership interest in a wholesaler is liable to the wholesaler for the laid-in costs of inventory of each affected brand of liquor and any diminution in the fair market value of the business of the wholesaler in relation to each affected brand. The damages recoverable pursuant to this section include, without limitation, all reasonable costs of bringing the action and attorneyï¿½s fees. For the purpose of this subsection, the fair market value of a business of a wholesaler includes, without limitation, the good will of the business and its value as a going concern, if any.

section.heading: Prohibited acts by supplier; exceptions; correction by wholesaler of alleged failure to comply with franchise.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 4, if more than one franchise for the same brand or brands of malt beverages, distilled spirits and wines, or all of them, is granted to different wholesalers in this state, it is a violation ofNRS 597.120to597.180, inclusive, for any supplier to discriminate between such wholesalers with respect to any of the terms, provisions and conditions of these franchises. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in this subsection and notwithstanding the terms, provisions or conditions of any franchise, a supplier shall not unilaterally terminate or refuse to continue any franchise with a wholesaler or cause a wholesaler to resign from that franchise unless the supplier has first established good cause for that termination, noncontinuance or causing of that resignation. This subsection does not apply to a supplier who sells less than 2,000 barrels of malt beverages, less than 250 cases of distilled spirits or less than 2,000 cases of wine in this state in any calendar year, or who operates a winery pursuant toNRS 597.240. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, a wholesaler may, within 60 days after he or she receives a notice required pursuant toNRS 597.155, correct any failure to comply with the terms, provisions and conditions of the franchise alleged by the supplier. This subsection does not apply to a supplier who sells less than 2,000 barrels of malt beverages, less than 250 cases of distilled spirits or less than 2,000 cases of wine in this State in any calendar year, or who operates a winery pursuant toNRS 597.240. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Unless otherwise specified by contract between the supplier and wholesaler, a supplier shall not grant more than one franchise to a wholesaler for any brand of alcoholic beverage in a marketing area.

section.heading: Additional prohibited acts by supplier.

content.p: Prevent a wholesaler from using best efforts to sell, market, advertise or promote an alcoholic beverage of any other supplier; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Provide any reward or penalty to, or in any other way condition its relationship with, a wholesaler based upon the amount of sales the wholesaler makes of an alcoholic beverage of any other supplier; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Disapprove a wholesalerï¿½s selection of a general manager or successor general manager based on the wholesalerï¿½s sales, marketing, advertising, promotion or retail placement of an alcoholic beverage of any other supplier; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Require a wholesaler to report to the supplier any of the wholesalerï¿½s financial information associated with the purchase, sale or distribution of an alcoholic beverage of any other supplier, except that nothing in this subsection prohibits a wholesaler from reporting general financial information in order for the supplier to assess the overall financial condition of a wholesaler as a condition of providing credit, so long as the supplier does not require the wholesaler to submit disaggregated financial information associated with or identifying the wholesalerï¿½s sales of an alcoholic beverage of another supplier or suppliers; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Require a wholesaler to pay to the supplier all or any portion of the difference in the suggested retail price of an alcoholic beverage and the actual price at which the wholesaler sells the alcoholic beverage; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Require a wholesaler to accept delivery of any alcoholic beverage or any other item that is not voluntarily ordered by the wholesaler or is in violation of any levels of inventory that are mutually agreed upon in writing by the supplier and wholesaler; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Prohibit or restrain, directly or indirectly, a wholesaler from participating in an organization that represents the interests of wholesalers for any lawful purpose; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Discriminate against, penalize or otherwise retaliate against a wholesaler because the wholesaler raises, alleges or otherwise brings to the attention of the Department of Taxation an actual, potential or perceived violation of this chapter or enter into an agreement with a wholesaler which purports to waive any right or remedy of the wholesaler pursuant to this subsection; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Require a wholesaler to participate in or contribute to any advertising fund or promotional activity that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is not used for advertising or a promotional activity in the marketing area of the wholesaler; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Fail to approve or disapprove an invoice or claim for reimbursement submitted by a wholesaler within 45 days after receipt of the invoice or claim; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Fail to pay to a wholesaler the amount of any invoice or claim for reimbursement within 45 days after the supplier approves the invoice or claim; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Require a wholesaler to make payments to the supplier under terms that are materially different from the payment terms applicable to the supplier when making payments to the wholesaler; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Withdraw credit or credit terms from a wholesaler except in accordance with the terms of a written policy of the supplier which is provided or otherwise made available to the wholesaler.

section.heading: Requiring wholesaler to increase payment for product prohibited after delivery by supplier.

content.p: A supplier shall not require a wholesaler to increase his or her payment to the supplier for any product of that supplier after the product is delivered to the wholesaler.

section.heading: Remedies of wholesaler.

content.p: Any wholesaler may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction against a supplier for violation ofNRS 597.120to597.180, inclusive, and may recover the damages sustained by the wholesaler, together with such costs of the action and reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees as are authorized underNRS 18.110. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The remedies provided inNRS 597.120to597.180, inclusive, are independent of and supplemental to any other remedy or remedies available to the wholesaler in law or equity.

section.heading: Term of contract or agreement that alters or waives provisions void and unenforceable.

content.p: Any term of a contract or other agreement that attempts to alter or waive any provision ofNRS 597.120to597.180, inclusive, is void and unenforceable.

section.heading: Action by wholesaler: Defense by supplier.

content.p: In any action brought by a wholesaler against a supplier for termination or noncontinuance of, or causing to resign from a franchise in violation ofNRS 597.120to597.180, inclusive, the supplier has the burden of establishing that he or she acted for good cause and that the wholesaler did not act in good faith. It is a complete defense for the supplier to prove that the termination, noncontinuance or causing to resign was done in good faith and for good cause.

section.heading: Statement of legislative policy.

content.p: It is the policy of the Legislature to insure the orderly distribution and marketing of alcoholic beverages in this state in order to protect locally owned and operated business enterprises and those residents whose livelihoods and investments are dependent on their freedom to manage their businesses without economic and coercive control by nonresident suppliers of alcoholic beverages.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: ï¿½Alcoholic beverageï¿½ means any malt beverage or spirituous, vinous or malt liquor which contains 1 percent or more ethyl alcohol by volume. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Brew pubï¿½ means an establishment which manufactures malt beverages and sells those malt beverages at retail pursuant to the provisions ofNRS 597.230. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Case of spiritsï¿½ means 12 bottles, each containing 750 milliliters of distilled spirits. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Craft distilleryï¿½ means an establishment which: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Manufactures distilled spirits from agricultural raw materials through distillation; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is authorized to sell those distilled spirits pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Distillationï¿½ means the process of producing or purifying spirituous liquor by successive evaporation and condensation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Engage inï¿½ includes participation in a business as an owner or partner, or through a subsidiary, affiliate, ownership equity or in any other manner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Estate distilleryï¿½ means an establishment which: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Manufactures distilled spirits from agricultural raw materials through distillation, provided that 85 percent of such agricultural raw materials, in the aggregate, were grown on land within this State which is owned or controlled by the owner of the distillery; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is authorized to sell those distilled spirits pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Instructional wine-making facilityï¿½ means an instructional wine-making facility operated pursuant toNRS 597.245. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Legal ageï¿½ means the age at which a person is legally permitted to purchase an alcoholic beverage pursuant toNRS 202.020. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Malt beverageï¿½ means beer, ale, porter, stout and other similar fermented beverages of any name or description, brewed or produced from malt, wholly or in part. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Special eventï¿½ means an event that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Lasts not longer than 1 calendar day; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Occurs at: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Supplierï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 597.140. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Wineï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 369.140.

section.heading: Limitations on engaging in business of importing, wholesaling or retailing alcoholic beverages.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, a person engaged in business as a supplier or engaged in the business of manufacturing, blending or bottling alcoholic beverages within or without this State shall not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Engage in the business of importing, wholesaling or retailing alcoholic beverages; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Operate or otherwise locate his or her business on the premises or property of another person engaged in the business of importing, wholesaling or retailing alcoholic beverages. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section does not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Preclude any person engaged in the business of importing, wholesaling or retailing alcoholic beverages from owning less than 2 percent of the outstanding ownership equity in any organization which manufactures, blends or bottles alcoholic beverages. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Prohibit a person engaged in the business of rectifying or bottling alcoholic beverages from importing neutral or distilled spirits in bulk only for the express purpose of rectification pursuant toNRS 369.415. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Prohibit a person from operating a brew pub pursuant toNRS 597.230. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Prohibit a person from operating an instructional wine-making facility pursuant toNRS 597.245. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Prohibit a person from operating a craft distillery pursuant toNRS 597.235. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Prohibit a person from operating an estate distillery pursuant toNRS 597.237. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Prohibit a person from operating a winery pursuant toNRS 597.240.

section.heading: Importer or wholesaler prohibited from engaging in business of retailing alcoholic beverages or operating or locating business on premises or property of supplier; exceptions.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided inNRS 597.235and597.237, a person who is engaged in the business of importing or wholesaling alcoholic beverages in the State of Nevada shall not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Engage in the business of retailing alcoholic beverages in this state; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Operate or otherwise locate his or her business on the premises or other property of any supplier. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

For the purposes of this section, a person who transfers or receives alcoholic beverages in the manner described inNRS 369.4865must not be considered to be engaged in the business of wholesaling alcoholic beverages based solely upon those transfers.

section.heading: Requirements to serve samples of alcoholic beverages on premises of grocery store; penalty.

content.p: A person who operates a grocery store may serve samples of alcoholic beverages on the premises of the grocery store if the person: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Obtains an annual permit to serve such samples from the local governing body that has jurisdiction to license and regulate the sale of alcoholic beverages on the premises of the grocery store; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Purchases any alcoholic beverages used for such samples from a wholesale dealer of alcoholic beverages who is licensed underchapter 369of NRS; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Complies with the requirements of this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A person who holds an annual permit issued pursuant to this section may serve samples of alcoholic beverages on the premises of the grocery store only to persons of legal age and only in such quantities as are necessary to provide a sample or taste of the alcoholic beverages. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a supplier, manufacturer, importer or wholesale dealer of alcoholic beverages may assist a person who operates a grocery store in serving samples of alcoholic beverages pursuant to this section. The assistance authorized by this subsection is limited to the pouring of such samples or the provision of information, instruction or education regarding the product being sampled, or any combination of those tasks. The provision of such assistance does not relieve the person who operates the grocery store from the responsibility of complying with all the requirements of this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A local governing body may adopt reasonable restrictions regarding the time, place, manner and frequency of the activities authorized by this section. Such restrictions must not prohibit or unreasonably interfere with the activities authorized by this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who serves samples of alcoholic beverages on the premises of a grocery store in violation of any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section preempts any local charter, code, ordinance or regulation that is in conflict with the purposes and objectives of this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A local governing body may not charge any fee for issuing an annual permit pursuant to this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

section.heading: Penalty; civil liability.

content.p: It is unlawful for a retailer of alcoholic beverages to substitute one brand of alcoholic beverage for a brand that has been specifically requested by the customer, unless the customer consents to the substitution. Any violation of this subsection by an employee must be attributed to the retailer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A retailer who violates the provisions of subsection 1: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the first offense, is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined an amount not to exceed $1,000, plus the costs of prosecution. No sentence of incarceration may be imposed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the second offense, is guilty of a gross misdemeanor and shall be fined an amount not to exceed $2,000, plus the costs of prosecution. No sentence of incarceration may be imposed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

For a third or subsequent offense, is guilty of a gross misdemeanor and shall be fined an amount equal to the costs of prosecution. The court shall impose no other criminal penalty, but shall, within 5 working days after the conviction, issue an order revoking the license to sell intoxicating liquor of the business and forward a certified copy of the order to the liquor board of county or governing body of the city, as applicable, which licensed the sale of liquor at the retailerï¿½s place of business. The board shall not reissue such a license for that place of business for a period of at least 1 year. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In addition to the criminal penalties set forth in this section, the retailer, upon conviction, is liable in civil suit to the customer and to the supplier and wholesaler of the requested alcoholic beverage for the damages which result from the substitution. The court shall award the prevailing party in such an action attorneyï¿½s fees and his or her costs of the action. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
