ï¿½Supplierï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 597.140. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Wholesalerï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 597.150.

section.heading: Enforcement by Attorney General and district attorneys; exceptions.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in this section andNRS 228.380, the Attorney General has primary jurisdiction to enforce the provisions ofNRS 597.120to597.260, inclusive, and shall cause appropriate legal action to be taken to enforce those provisions. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Attorney General has concurrent jurisdiction with the district attorneys of this State to enforce the provisions ofNRS 597.225and597.245. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section does not prohibit: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A wholesaler from bringing an action against a supplier pursuant toNRS 597.157or597.170. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A customer, supplier or wholesaler from bringing an action against a retailer pursuant toNRS 597.260.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: As used inNRS 597.264to597.2667, inclusive, unless the context otherwise requires the words and terms defined inNRS 597.2643to597.265, inclusive, have the meanings ascribed to them in those sections.

section.heading: ï¿½Assistive deviceï¿½ defined.

content.p: Hearing aids, devices for telecommunication and any other devices that enhance the ability of a person to hear; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Voice synthesizers, optical scanners, Braille printers and any other devices that enhance the ability of a person to communicate; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Light amplifiers, magnification equipment, Braille equipment and any other devices that enhance the ability of a person to see; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any other device that enhances the ability of a person to move, hear, communicate or see.

section.heading: ï¿½Consumerï¿½ defined.

content.p: A person to whom an assistive device is transferred during the period the express warranty of a manufacturer is in effect; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any other person who is entitled by the terms of the warranty to enforce its obligations.

section.heading: ï¿½Dealerï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Dealerï¿½ means a person who sells or leases assistive devices to consumers.

section.heading: ï¿½Manufacturerï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Manufacturerï¿½ means a person who manufactures or assembles assistive devices or an agent of that person, including an importer or a distributor. The term does not include a dealer.

section.heading: Manufacturer to provide express warranty for new assistive device; effective period of warranty; failure to provide warranty.

content.p: A manufacturer who, directly or through a dealer, sells or leases to a consumer in this state an assistive device that has not been previously sold or leased shall provide an express warranty for that device. The express warranty does not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Take effect until the consumer takes possession of the device; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Expire less than 1 year after the delivery of the device to the consumer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If a manufacturer fails to provide an express warranty required by this section, the assistive device shall be deemed to be covered by the express warranty of the manufacturer.

section.heading: Repair of assistive device not in conformance with express warranty.

content.p: If an assistive device does not conform to the express warranty of the manufacturer and the consumer reports the nonconformity to the manufacturer or dealer and makes the assistive device available for repair before the expiration of the express warranty, the manufacturer or dealer shall make the repairs necessary to conform the assistive device to the express warranty without regard to whether the repairs will be made after the expiration of the express warranty.

If, after a reasonable number of repairs, the manufacturer or dealer is unable to conform the assistive device to the express warranty and the defect or condition causing the nonconformity substantially impairs the use and value of the assistive device to the consumer and is not the result of abuse, neglect or unauthorized modifications or alterations of the assistive device by the consumer, the manufacturer shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Replace the assistive device with an assistive device of the same model and having the same features as the replaced device, or if such a device cannot be delivered to the consumer within a reasonable period, a comparable assistive device substantially similar to the replaced device; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Accept the return of the assistive device from the consumer and refund to the consumer, within 30 days after the return of the device, the purchase price of the device, including all sales taxes and finance charges paid by the consumer, and any other expenses related to the purchase and use of the assistive device, less a reasonable allowance for use of the assistive device. As used in this paragraph ï¿½reasonable allowance for useï¿½ means that amount that is directly attributable to the use of the device by the consumer before his or her first report of the nonconformity to the manufacturer or dealer and during any subsequent period that the assistive device is not out of service for repairs. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
It is presumed that a reasonable number of repairs have been undertaken to conform an assistive device to an applicable express warranty if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The same nonconformity has been subject to repair three or more times by the manufacturer or dealer within the time the express warranty is in effect, but the nonconformity continues to exist; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The assistive device is unavailable for use by the consumer because of a nonconformity for a cumulative total of 30 days or more within the period the express warranty is in effect, except that if the necessary repairs cannot be made for reasons which are beyond the control of the manufacturer or dealer, the number of days required to give rise to the presumption must be appropriately extended.

section.heading: Manufacturer to reimburse consumer for rental of assistive device in certain circumstances; action against dealer for failure to deliver assistive device for repair in timely manner.

content.p: If an assistive device covered by an express warranty of a manufacturer is made available for repair pursuant toNRS 597.2655and: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The device is not repaired within 10 working days, including the day on which the assistive device is made available for repair; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The defect or malfunction that is the cause of nonconformity is the same defect or malfunction for which the assistive device has been made available for repair two or more times, ï¿½the manufacturer shall provide to the consumer, for the duration of the period of repair, a reimbursement of not more than $30 each day for the rental of an assistive device. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a dealer does not deliver the assistive device to the manufacturer in a timely manner that allows the manufacturer to repair the device within 10 working days, the manufacturer may bring an action against the dealer for reimbursement of any money that the manufacturer is required to pay to a consumer pursuant to subsection 1.

section.heading: Sale or lease of returned assistive device prohibited unless reason for return disclosed to prospective consumer.

content.p: An assistive device that is returned to a manufacturer by a consumer in this state pursuant toNRS 597.2657may not be sold or leased in this state unless the reason for the return of the assistive device is disclosed to the prospective consumer.

section.heading: Action for damages and equitable relief; costs and attorneyï¿½s fees.

content.p: In addition to any other remedy available to a consumer, a consumer may bring an action to recover any damages caused by a manufacturer or dealer who violates any of the provisions ofNRS 597.264to597.2667, inclusive. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The court shall award to the prevailing party not more than twice the amount of the damages, and costs, including attorneyï¿½s fees and any equitable relief that the court determines is appropriate.

section.heading: Rights and remedies not exclusive; waiver of rights void.

content.p: The provisions ofNRS 597.264to597.2667, inclusive, do not limit any rights or remedies a consumer may have pursuant to any other law or agreement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A waiver by a consumer of any of the rights provided pursuant toNRS 597.264to597.2667, inclusive, is void.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: As used inNRS 597.270to597.470, inclusive, unless the context requires otherwise, the words and terms defined inNRS 597.280to597.380, inclusive, have the meanings ascribed to them in those sections.

section.heading: ï¿½Affiliateï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Affiliateï¿½ means any person who controls, is controlled by or is under common control with any other person.

section.heading: ï¿½Controlï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Controlï¿½ means the direct or indirect ownership of, or right to exercise a directing influence over, more than 50 percent of the beneficial interest in any other person.

section.heading: ï¿½Franchiseï¿½ and ï¿½franchise agreementï¿½ defined.

content.p: To use a trademark, trade name, service mark or other identifying symbol or name owned by the refiner; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To occupy premises owned, leased or controlled by the refiner, for the purpose of engaging in the retail sale of motor vehicle fuel.

section.heading: ï¿½Lessee dealerï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Lessee dealerï¿½ means a retailer who operates a service station pursuant to a franchise agreement if the service station is leased to the retailer by the refiner with whom the retailer has entered into the franchise agreement.

section.heading: ï¿½Marketing areaï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Marketing areaï¿½ means an area of not more than 5 miles in any direction from a service station selling the products of a refiner pursuant to a franchise.

section.heading: ï¿½Motor vehicle fuelï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Motor vehicle fuelï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 365.060, except that it includes diesel fuel.

section.heading: ï¿½Priceï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Priceï¿½ means the net purchase price after any adjustment for a commission, fee, rebate or discount, or for the furnishing of services or facilities.

section.heading: ï¿½Refinerï¿½ defined.

content.p: Produced quantities of crude oil equal to more than 30 percent of the domestic and imported crude oil supplied to his or her refinery during the most recent calendar year for which information is available; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Refines motor vehicle fuel from crude oil; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has a total refinery capacity of more than 175,000 barrels a day.

section.heading: ï¿½Refineryï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Refineryï¿½ means a manufacturing facility at which motor vehicle fuel is produced from crude oil.

section.heading: ï¿½Retailerï¿½ defined.

content.p: Wholesale purchaser; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Person who operates a service station pursuant to a franchise agreement with a refiner or wholesale purchaser.

section.heading: ï¿½Service stationï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Service stationï¿½ means an establishment where motor vehicle fuel is sold to the general public.

section.heading: ï¿½Wholesale purchaserï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Wholesale purchaserï¿½ means any person who purchases motor vehicle fuel or other petroleum products from a refiner or other wholesaler for distribution to service stations or to individual or business consumers.

section.heading: Prohibited practices of refiners.

content.p: Prohibit, directly or indirectly, the right of free association among retailers or wholesale purchasers for any lawful purpose. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Change or modify any restrictions upon business activities of a retailer during the term of the franchise that are not related to the sale of motor vehicle fuel or other petroleum products. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Unreasonably reduce, limit or curtail the supply of motor vehicle fuel or other petroleum products to any retailer or wholesale purchaser. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Place unreasonable restrictions upon business activities of a retailer that are not related to the sale of motor vehicle fuel or other petroleum products or upon any business activities of a wholesale purchaser.

section.heading: Circumstances under which fair compensation is required on failure of refiner to renew franchise.

content.p: A refiner shall not fail to renew the franchise of any retailer without fairly compensating the retailer at a fair going business value for his or her capital investment if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The capital investment was entered into with reasonable and prudent business judgment for the purpose of fulfilling the franchise; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The cancellation or failure to renew was not done in good faith. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

For the purposes of this section, ï¿½capital investmentï¿½ includes, but is not limited to, tools, equipment and any inventory of parts possessed by the retailer on the day of notification of cancellation or nonrenewal and which are still in the retailerï¿½s possession on the day the cancellation or nonrenewal is effective.

section.heading: Required notice of termination, cancellation or failure to renew franchise or contract.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2 or 3, a refiner shall not, directly or indirectly, or through an officer, agent or employee terminate, cancel or fail to renew a franchise or a contract with a wholesale purchaser without first giving to the retailer or wholesale purchaser written notice as follows: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In case of cancellation or termination, specifying all matters of claimed noncompliance with the agreement and allowing the other party at least 30 days to comply with the terms of the agreement. If the other party does not comply, the cancellation or termination is effective on the date set forth in the notice. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
At least 30 days before the expiration of a term of an agreement, specifying: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
All the reasons for any intention of the refiner not to renew; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any change in price, rent, terms or conditions to which renewal of the agreement is subject. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the alleged ground is voluntary abandonment by the retailer of the franchise, or by the wholesale purchaser of his or her contract, the written notice may be given 3 days before the termination or cancellation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the alleged ground is the conviction of the retailer of a crime punishable as a felony and related to the business conducted pursuant to the franchise, termination, cancellation or failure to renew may be effective immediately.

section.heading: Effect of failure to serve notice.

content.p: The failure of a refiner to serve notice upon a retailer or wholesale purchaser as required inNRS 597.410constitutes a grant of the option by the refiner to the retailer or wholesale purchaser to renew the franchise or contract for a period of 1 year under the same price, rent, terms and conditions as the expiring agreement. The option expires 45 days after the date when notice should have been served, unless exercised by written notice to the refiner.

section.heading: Manner of giving notice.

content.p: The address indicated in the agreement or as subsequently changed by the party in writing; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If no address was designated, the partyï¿½s place of business.

section.heading: Restrictions on refinerï¿½s operation of service stations.

content.p: Less than 30 service stations in this state, with his or her own employees or through a subsidiary or commissioned agent or a person on the basis of a fee, may commence the direct operation of not more than 5 additional service stations per calendar year, but in no case may the refiner commence the direct operation of more than 30 service stations without complying with the provisions of subsection 2. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

At least 30 service stations in this state, with his or her own employees or through a subsidiary or commissioned agent or a person on the basis of a fee, may commence the direct operation of additional service stations per year, with his or her own employees or through a subsidiary or commissioned agent or person on the basis of a fee, only if, during the year in which the service stations are added, the refiner leases, in addition to the number of service stations leased by the refiner to lessee dealers on July 1, 1997, at least 1 additional service station to a lessee dealer for every 2 directly operated service stations added. For the purposes of this subsection, an additional service station leased by the refiner to a lessee dealer before the refiner engages in the direct operation of at least 30 service stations shall be deemed to be 1 service station leased to a lessee dealer during any year following the year in which the refiner engages in the direct operation of at least 30 service stations.

section.heading: Temporary operation of service station by refiner; limitations on temporary operation; price of motor vehicle fuel sold to other retailers.

content.p: If a refiner is unable to commence the direct operation of a service station because of the restrictions set forth inNRS 597.440, the refiner may operate the service station temporarily for not more than 180 days if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The retailer voluntarily terminates or agrees not to renew the franchise for the service station; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The franchise for the service station is terminated by the refiner pursuant toNRS 597.270to597.470, inclusive. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

During the temporary operation of a service station by a refiner, the refiner may sell motor vehicle fuel to other retailers in the marketing area of that service station at a price not less than 4 cents below the retail price of fuel at the service station the refiner is operating.

section.heading: Refinerï¿½s failure to act in good faith or use of undue influence prohibited.

content.p: Fail to act in good faith in performing or complying with any term or provision of, or collateral to, a franchise or a contract with a wholesale purchaser. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Use undue influence to induce a retailer to surrender any right given to the retailer by any provision contained in the franchise.

section.heading: Judicial relief; costs and attorneyï¿½s fees.

content.p: A retailer, wholesale purchaser or refiner may bring an action against the other party for violation of their respective agreements and may: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Recover the damages sustained. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Obtain injunctive relief to prevent loss of rights or restore rights lost. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The remedies provided in this section are independent of and supplemental to any other remedy available to the retailer, wholesale purchaser or refiner in law or equity. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In any action under this section the prevailing party is entitled to recover from the losing party all costs incurred, including reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: ï¿½Buyerï¿½ means: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who purchases or contracts to purchase, other than for purposes of resale, a motor vehicle normally used for personal, family or household purposes. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any person to whom the motor vehicle is transferred during the time a manufacturerï¿½s express warranty applicable to the motor vehicle is in effect. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any other person entitled by the terms of the warranty to enforce its obligations. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, ï¿½motor vehicleï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 482.075. The term does not include motor homes or off-road vehicles except for the purposes ofNRS 597.680.

section.heading: Report of defect in motor vehicle; duty of manufacturer.

content.p: Before the expiration of the manufacturerï¿½s express warranties; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

No later than 1 year after the date the motor vehicle is delivered to the original buyer, ï¿½whichever occurs earlier, the manufacturer, its agent or its authorized dealer shall make such repairs as are necessary to conform the vehicle to the express warranties without regard to whether the repairs will be made after the expiration of the express warranty or the time described in subsection 2.

section.heading: Submission of claim to manufacturer for replacement or refund according to designated procedure.

content.p: If the manufacturer has established or designated a procedure for settling disputes informally which substantially complies with the provisions of Title 16 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 703, a buyer must first submit his or her claim for replacement of the motor vehicle or for refund of the purchase price under that procedure before bringing any action underNRS 597.630.

section.heading: Duties of manufacturer if motor vehicle cannot be conformed to express warranties.

content.p: If, after a reasonable number of attempts, the manufacturer, or its agent or authorized dealer is unable to conform the motor vehicle to any applicable express warranty by repair or correction and the defect or condition causing the nonconformity substantially impairs the use and value of the motor vehicle to the buyer and is not the result of abuse, neglect or unauthorized modifications or alterations of the motor vehicle, the manufacturer shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Replace the motor vehicle with a comparable motor vehicle of the same model and having the same features as the replaced vehicle, or if such a vehicle cannot be delivered to the buyer within a reasonable time, then a comparable motor vehicle substantially similar to the replaced vehicle; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Accept return of the motor vehicle from the buyer and refund to him or her the full purchase price including all sales taxes, license fees, registration fees and other similar governmental charges, less a reasonable allowance for his or her use of the vehicle. A reasonable allowance for use is that amount directly attributable to use by the buyer before his or her first report of the nonconformity to the manufacturer, agent or dealer and during any subsequent period when the vehicle is not out of service for repairs. Refunds must be made to the buyer, and lienholder if any, as their interests may appear. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
It is presumed that a reasonable number of attempts have been undertaken to conform a motor vehicle to the applicable express warranties where: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The same nonconformity has been subject to repair four or more times by the manufacturer, or its agent or authorized dealer within the time the express warranty is in effect or within 1 year following the date the motor vehicle is delivered to the original buyer, whichever occurs earlier, but the nonconformity continues to exist; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The motor vehicle is out of service for repairs for a cumulative total of 30 or more calendar days within the time the express warranty is in effect or within 1 year following the date the motor vehicle is delivered to the original buyer, whichever occurs earlier, except that if the necessary repairs cannot be made for reasons which are beyond the control of the manufacturer or its agent or authorized dealer, the number of days required to give rise to the presumption must be appropriately extended.

section.heading: Tolling of period for express warranties.

content.p: For the purposes ofNRS 597.600to597.670, inclusive, the running of the time an express warranty is in effect or of any other period of time described in those sections is tolled for the time during which services to repair the motor vehicle are not reasonably available to the buyer because of a war, invasion or strike, or because of a fire, flood or other natural disaster.

section.heading: Commencement of action by buyer.

content.p: Any action brought pursuant toNRS 597.600to597.630, inclusive, must be commenced within 18 months after the date of the original delivery of the motor vehicle to the buyer.

section.heading: Waiver of rights by buyer prohibited.

content.p: Any provision in any agreement between the manufacturer or its agent or authorized dealer and the buyer which provides that the buyer agrees to waive or forego any rights or remedies afforded byNRS 597.600to597.630, inclusive, is void.

section.heading: Effect on other rights and remedies of buyer.

content.p: The provisions ofNRS 597.600to597.630, inclusive, do not limit any other right or remedy which the buyer may have by law or by agreement.

section.heading: Notification of manufacturer regarding change in residential address.

content.p: Any person entitled by the terms of a manufacturerï¿½s express warranty to enforce its obligations is responsible for notifying the manufacturer of any change in his or her residential address.

section.heading: Reimbursement by manufacturer for cost of repairs to conform vehicle to express warranties.

content.p: The manufacturer shall reimburse its agent or authorized dealer for the cost of repairs made to a motor vehicle to conform it to the manufacturerï¿½s express warranties. The reimbursement must be paid at the rate usually billed by the agent or dealer to the general public for similar repairs.

section.heading: Lemon Law Buyback: General duties regarding retitling, notice and disclosures.

content.p: A manufacturer, or its agent or authorized dealer, who reacquires a motor vehicle pursuantNRS 597.630that was registered in this State, or any other state, the District of Columbia or any territory or possession of the United States, or who assists a lienholder in reacquiring such a motor vehicle, shall, before selling, leasing or transferring ownership of the motor vehicle in this State or exporting the motor vehicle to another state for sale, lease or transfer: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Request the Department of Motor Vehicles to inscribe the certificate of ownership for the motor vehicle with the notation ï¿½Lemon Law Buybackï¿½; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Affix a decal to the motor vehicle in accordance with subsection 6. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any manufacturer who reacquires, or assists a dealer or lienholder in reacquiring, a motor vehicle in response to a request by the buyer or lessee that the motor vehicle be replaced or accepted for a refund because the motor vehicle did not conform to express warranties shall, before the sale, lease or other transfer of the motor vehicle, execute and deliver to the subsequent transferee a notice and obtain the transfereeï¿½s written acknowledgment of the notice in accordance withNRS 597.684. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any person, including any dealer, who acquires a motor vehicle for resale and knows that the motor vehicle was reacquired by the manufacturer of the motor vehicle pursuant toNRS 597.630shall, before the sale, lease or other transfer, execute and deliver to the subsequent transferee a notice and obtain the transfereeï¿½s written acknowledgment of the notice in accordance withNRS 597.684. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any person, including any manufacturer or dealer, who sells, leases or transfers ownership of a motor vehicle when the certificate of ownership for the motor vehicle is inscribed with the notation ï¿½Lemon Law Buybackï¿½ shall, before the sale, lease, or ownership transfer of the motor vehicle, submit to the transferee a written disclosure signed by the transferee stating that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ THIS VEHICLE WAS REPURCHASED BY ITS MANUFACTURER BECAUSE OF A DEFECT IN THE VEHICLE PURSUANT TO CONSUMER WARRANTY LAWS. THE TITLE TO THIS VEHICLE HAS BEEN PERMANENTLY INSCRIBED WITH THE NOTATION ï¿½LEMON LAW BUYBACK.ï¿½ ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The requirements for disclosure set forth in subsections 1, 2 and 3 are in addition to any other notice requirements for consumers and do not relieve any person, including any dealer or manufacturer, from complying with any other applicable law. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The decal required pursuant to subsection 1 must be affixed to the left front doorframe of the motor vehicle or, if the motor vehicle does not have a left front doorframe, in a location designated by the Department of Motor Vehicles. The decal must specify that the certificate of title to the motor vehicle has been permanently inscribed with the notation ï¿½Lemon Law Buyback.ï¿½ A person shall not knowingly remove or alter any decal affixed to a motor vehicle pursuant to this subsection, regardless of whether the motor vehicle is licensed pursuant to this chapter.

section.heading: Lemon Law Buyback: Form of notice.

content.p: The notice required pursuant to subsections 1, 2 and 3 ofNRS 597.682must be prepared by the manufacturer of the reacquired motor vehicle and specify: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The year, make, model and vehicle identification number of the motor vehicle. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Whether the certificate of title for the motor vehicle has been inscribed with the notation ï¿½Lemon Law Buyback.ï¿½ ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The nature of each nonconformity reported by the original buyer or lessee of the motor vehicle. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The repairs, if any, made to the motor vehicle in an attempt to correct each nonconformity reported by the original buyer or lessee. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The notice must be included on a form 8 1/2 x 11 inches in size and printed in a size equal to at least 10-point black type on a white background. content.p: A person, including, without limitation, a commercial user, shall not remanufacture, retrofit, sell, contract to sell or resell, lease, sublet or otherwise place in the stream of commerce a crib that is unsafe for use by an infant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

16 C.F.R. Part 1303; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The American Society for Testing and Materials voluntary standards F966-90, F1169.88 and F406. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Cribs that are presumed to be unsafe pursuant to subsection 2 also include, without limitation, cribs with one or more of the following features or characteristics: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

of subsection 3, a mattress support is deemed to be easily dislodged if it cannot withstand a 25-pound upward force from beneath the crib.

section.heading: Legislative findings and declarations.

content.p: Electric utilities in this State are responsible for delivering safe, reliable energy through large transmission and distribution networks. Equipment failure or damage from weather, animals and human activity can cause power outages. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Electric utilities report that foil balloons are among the top causes of outages. Foil balloons are coated with a shiny metallic film that conducts electricity. If a foil balloon contacts power lines, this can create an electrical fault that can damage power lines, cause blackouts and start fires. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Because of the risk of power outages and fires caused by foil balloons coming into contact with power lines, other states and jurisdictions have considered bans on foil balloons. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Modern technology has advanced to allow for the manufacturing of foil balloons that resist conducting electricity. The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers is developing standards for such balloons. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Requiring foil balloons to be tested and to meet performance standards concerning their dielectric performance will minimize the risks of power outages and fires.

Not less than 80 percent of the foil balloons sold, offered for sale or manufactured by the person comply with the provisions of this section on or before June 30, 2029. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
One hundred percent of the foil balloons sold, offered for sale or manufactured by the person comply with the provisions of this section on or before June 30, 2030. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A period described in subsection 3 must be tolled during any period in which a serious development, manufacturing, production or supply chain issue or event in the nature of force majeure occurs if the issue or event: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Makes it infeasible to develop, manufacture, produce or sell foil balloons in compliance with the requirements of this section; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is outside of the control of the person who sells, offers to sell or manufactures a foil balloon in this State. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If a period of tolling is required pursuant to subsection 4, the period must be: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Twenty-four months; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Until the serious development, manufacturing, production or supply chain issue or event in the nature of force majeure is resolved, ï¿½whichever occurs later. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

As used in this section, ï¿½infeasibleï¿½ means incapable of being accomplished in a successful manner within a reasonable time, taking into account economic, environmental, legal, social and technological factors.

section.heading: Adoption of standards for testing and evaluating dielectric performance.

content.p: The Commission shall adopt, by regulation, a standard for testing and evaluating the dielectric performance of foil balloons. If the P2845 Standard is final and approved, the Commission shall adopt the P2845 Standard as the standard required by this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the purposes of subsection 1, the P2845 Standard shall be deemed to be final and approved if the Institute for Electrical and Electronics Engineers has: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Completed a trial of the interim version of the P2845 Standard; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
After any materially substantive adjustments, if any, to the interim version, published a final version of the P2845 Standard.

A person who sells, offers for sale or manufactures a foil balloon in violation ofNRS 597.717to597.7179, inclusive, is subject to a civil penalty not to exceed $50 for each such foil balloon sold, offered for sale or manufactured, except that the penalty against the person must not exceed $2,500 for each day on which a violation occurs. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A civil penalty imposed pursuant to subsection 1 must be recovered in a civil action brought by the Attorney General or by the district attorney or city attorney for the jurisdiction in which the violation occurred. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any civil penalty collected pursuant to this section by: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Attorney General must be paid to the State Treasurer for credit to the State General Fund. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A district attorney or city attorney must be deposited in the county or city treasury, as applicable. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In determining whether to impose a civil penalty pursuant to subsection 1, the court shall consider: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Whether the person took good faith measures to comply with the requirements ofNRS 597.717to597.7179, inclusive, and when such measures were taken; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The deterrent effect that the imposition of the penalty would have on both the person and the regulated community as a whole; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The willfulness of the person responsible for the violation; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any other factors that justice may require. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Attorney General or the district attorney or city attorney of a county or city, as applicable, in which a person sells, offers for sale or manufactures a foil balloon in violation ofNRS 597.717to597.7179, inclusive, may bring an action to enjoin the violation.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: ï¿½Artistï¿½ means a person who creates a work of art. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Reproductionï¿½ means a copy, in any medium, of a work of art, that is represented as the work of art as created by the artist. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Work of artï¿½ means any original creation of visual or graphic art in any medium including painting, drawing, photographic print or sculpture of a limited edition of not more than 300 copies. The term does not include: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Sequential imagery such as that in motion pictures. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Work prepared under contract for commercial use by the purchaser. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Work prepared by the employee of a publisher during the course of his or her employment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Work submitted for publication at no charge.

section.heading: Right to claim or disclaim authorship.

content.p: Claim authorship of his or her work of art. The right to claim authorship includes the right of the artist to have his or her name appear on or with his or her work of art. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Disclaim authorship of his or her work of art if necessary to protect his or her reputation from damage. It is presumed necessary for an artist to protect his or her reputation from damage if his or her work of art is displayed, published or reproduced in this state, without his or her consent, in a defaced, mutilated or altered form and damage to his or her reputation is reasonably foreseeable.

section.heading: Restrictions on publication and public display; civil remedy; defacement, mutilation or alteration of work.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, if damage to the reputation of an artist is reasonably foreseeable, a person shall not, without the consent of that artist, publish or display in public, in this state, the artistï¿½s work of art or a reproduction of the artistï¿½s work of art, in a defaced, mutilated or altered form and represent it as the work of the artist. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An artist who is injured by a violation of subsection 1 may bring an action for damages, together with reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees and the costs of the action as are authorized underNRS 18.110. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Defacement, mutilation or alteration of a work of art which is caused by the passage of time or the inherent nature of the materials used in the creation of the work of art does not give an artist the right to disclaim authorship pursuant toNRS 597.730or a cause of action under subsection 2, unless the defacement, mutilation or alteration of the work of art is the result of negligent conservation. For the purposes of this subsection, ï¿½conservationï¿½ means those acts taken to preserve and protect a work of art or to slow its deterioration. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A change in a work of art that is an ordinary result of a medium of reproduction does not constitute defacement, mutilation or alteration.

section.heading: Waiver of rights.

content.p: An artist may waive, in writing, his or her rights underNRS 597.720to597.760, inclusive.

section.heading: Transfer of ownership or right of reproduction.

content.p: When ownership of a work of art is transferred from the artist who created it or his or her heirs, the right of reproduction remains with the artist or his or her heirs until it passes into the public domain by act or operation of law or is expressly transferred in writing. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

When an exclusive or nonexclusive right of reproduction is transferred by the owner of such right, it must be presumed that ownership of the physical work of art remains with the owner of the work of art unless it is expressly transferred in writing with the right of reproduction. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

For the purposes of this section ï¿½right of reproductionï¿½ means the right to reproduce, display and distribute copies of a work of art. The term includes the right to prepare variations of the original work of art.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: As used inNRS 597.761to597.7622, inclusive, unless the context otherwise requires, the words and terms defined inNRS 597.7612to597.7616, inclusive, have the meanings ascribed to them in those sections.

section.heading: ï¿½Operatorï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Operatorï¿½ means a person who is designated by the owner of a tanning establishment or by the lessee of the tanning equipment of the tanning establishment to operate or to assist and instruct in the operation and use of the tanning establishment or tanning equipment.

section.heading: ï¿½Ownerï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Ownerï¿½ means the owner of a tanning establishment.

section.heading: ï¿½Phototherapy deviceï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Phototherapy deviceï¿½ means any equipment that emits ultraviolet radiation and is used in the diagnosis or treatment of disease or injury.

section.heading: ï¿½Tanning equipmentï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Tanning equipmentï¿½ means any device that emits ultraviolet radiation to tan human skin, including, without limitation, sunlamps, tanning booths and tanning beds.

section.heading: ï¿½Tanning establishmentï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Tanning establishmentï¿½ means any premises, mobile unit, building or part of a building where access to tanning equipment is provided for a fee, membership dues or any other compensation.

section.heading: Owner or operator: Prohibited acts.

content.p: An owner or operator shall not allow a person who is less than 18 years of age to use the tanning equipment of a tanning establishment.

section.heading: Owner or operator: Duty to post notice in tanning establishment.

content.p: It is unlawful for the owner or operator of a tanning establishment to allow a person who is less than 18 years of age to use any tanning equipment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An owner or operator of a tanning establishment who violates any provision ofNRS 597.761to597.7622, inclusive, may be subject to civil action. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any person may report a violation ofNRS 597.761to597.7622, inclusive, to any law enforcement agency. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Health risks associated with tanning include, without limitation, skin cancer, premature aging of the skin and burns to the skin.

section.heading: Owner or operator: Duty to post warning sign in tanning establishment; civil penalty for violation.

content.p: An owner or operator shall post in a conspicuous place in each area where tanning equipment is used a warning sign that states substantially the following: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Follow instructions. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Avoid too frequent or too lengthy exposure. Like exposure to the sun, use of tanning equipment can cause eye and skin injury and allergic reactions. Repeated exposure can cause chronic sun damage, which is characterized by wrinkling, dryness, fragility and bruising of the skin and skin cancer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Wear protective eyewear. Failure to do so may result in severe burns or long-term injury to the eyes. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Medications and cosmetics may increase your sensitivity to ultraviolet radiation. Consult a physician before using tanning equipment if you are using medications, have a history of skin problems or believe that you are especially sensitive to sunlight. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If your skin does not tan when exposed to the sun, it is unlikely that your skin will tan when exposed to this tanning equipment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An owner or operator who fails to post a warning sign in accordance with subsection 1 shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the first violation, pay a civil penalty of $250. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the second violation, pay a civil penalty of $500. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the third or subsequent violation, pay a civil penalty of $1,000.

section.heading: Owner or operator: Additional duties.

content.p: A person who is qualified to operate the tanning equipment and who is able to inform users about, and assist such users in, the proper use of tanning equipment is present at the tanning establishment during operating hours. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Tanning equipment is properly sanitized after each use. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Each user, before he or she begins to use tanning equipment, is provided with properly sanitized and securely fitting protective eyewear that protects the wearerï¿½s eyes from ultraviolet radiation and allows enough vision to maintain balance. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Users wear the protective eyewear described in subsection 3 when using tanning equipment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Each user is shown how to maintain the proper exposure distance from the tanning equipment as recommended by the manufacturer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A timing device which is accurate within 10 percent of any selected time interval is used and is remotely located so a user cannot set his or her own exposure time when using tanning equipment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Tanning equipment is equipped with a mechanism that allows the user to turn off the tanning equipment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Each user is limited to the maximum exposure time recommended by the manufacturer for his or her skin type. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A user is not allowed to use the tanning equipment more than once in any 24-hour period. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The interior temperature of the tanning equipment does not exceed 100 degrees Fahrenheit. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Acknowledgments signed by each user indicating that he or she understands the notices and warnings prescribed byNRS 597.7618and597.7619, and that he or she agrees to use protective eyewear, are retained for at least 1 year or until the user signs a new acknowledgment.

section.heading: Action by parent or guardian of minor against owner or operator for certain violations.

content.p: A parent or guardian of a person who is less than 18 years of age may bring an action against an owner or operator if the owner or operator violatesNRS 597.7617. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In any action brought pursuant to this section, if a parent or guardian of a person who is less than 18 years of age establishes that the owner or operator violatedNRS 597.7617, a court shall award the parent or guardian, in addition to costs and reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the first occurrence, $500. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the second occurrence, $1,000. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the third or subsequent occurrence, $1,500. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Each instance in which an owner or operator allows a person who is less than 18 years of age to use the tanning equipment of the tanning establishment in violation ofNRS 597.7617constitutes a separate occurrence.

section.heading: Exceptions.

content.p: The provisions ofNRS 597.761to597.7622, inclusive, do not apply to any physician licensed to practice medicine in this State who uses, or prescribes the use of, a phototherapy device, or to any person who is prescribed the use of a phototherapy device by a physician licensed to practice medicine in this State.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: As used inNRS 597.7625to597.7642, inclusive, unless the context otherwise requires, the words and terms defined inNRS 597.7626to597.7634, inclusive, have the meanings ascribed to them in those sections.

section.heading: ï¿½Commissionï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Commissionï¿½ means any fee or other payment of money that is charged by a food delivery service platform provider to a food dispensing establishment for the use of the services of the food delivery service platform provider in effectuating online food orders. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The term includes, without limitation, any annual fee charged to a food dispensing establishment for the use of the services described in subsection 1. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The term does include any fee that is charged by a food delivery service platform provider for services provided as a general or indirect cost of doing business, including, without limitation, fees for the processing of credit cards or for advertising in a restaurant directory.

section.heading: ï¿½Food delivery service platformï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Food delivery service platformï¿½ means an Internet website, online service or mobile application which allows users to purchase food from multiple food dispensing establishments and arrange for the same-day delivery or same-day pickup of such food. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The term does not include an Internet website, online service or mobile application which does not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Post the menu of, the amounts charged by or the likeness, registered trademark or intellectual property of a food dispensing establishment; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Charge a commission or other payment of money to a food dispensing establishment in effectuating online food orders.

section.heading: ï¿½Food delivery service platform providerï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Food delivery service platform providerï¿½ means a person who operates a food delivery service platform.

section.heading: ï¿½Food dispensing establishmentï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Food dispensing establishmentï¿½ means a food establishment that prepares and serves food intended for immediate consumption. The term includes, without limitation, a restaurant. The term does not include a convenience store or a grocery store. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Convenience storeï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 597.225. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Food establishmentï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 446.020. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Grocery storeï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 597.225.

section.heading: ï¿½Food purchase priceï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Food purchase priceï¿½ means the portion of the total online food order price that is attributable to the amount charged by the food dispensing establishment for the food.

section.heading: ï¿½Likenessï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Likenessï¿½ means any identifiable symbol attributed and easily identified as belonging to a specific food dispensing establishment.

section.heading: ï¿½Online food orderï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Online food orderï¿½ means a transaction in which a user, through a food delivery service platform, purchases food from a food dispensing establishment and arranges for the same-day delivery or same-day pickup of such food.

section.heading: ï¿½Total online food order priceï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Total online food order priceï¿½ means the total amount paid or to be paid by a user as a result of an online food order.

section.heading: ï¿½Userï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Userï¿½ means a person who uses a food delivery service platform to engage in an online food order.

section.heading: Facilitation of online food order without written agreement with food dispensing establishment prohibited.

content.p: A food delivery service platform provider shall not facilitate an online food order involving a food dispensing establishment, including, without limitation, arranging for the same-day delivery or same-day pickup of food prepared by a food dispensing establishment, unless the food delivery service platform provider has entered into a written agreement with the food dispensing establishment that expressly authorizes the food delivery service platform provider to engage in such activities.

section.heading: Request of food dispensing establishment for removal from food delivery service platform; duty of food delivery service platform provider that receives request; civil penalties.

content.p: A food dispensing establishment may, at any time, submit a written request to a food delivery service platform provider directing the provider to remove the food dispensing establishment from the food delivery service platform. If the food delivery service platform provider has appointed a registered agent located in this State, the request must be submitted to the registered agent. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A food delivery service platform provider that receives a request submitted pursuant to subsection 1 shall confirm receipt of the request and remove the food dispensing establishment from the food delivery service platform within 48 hours after receipt of the request. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A food delivery service platform provider who violates the provisions of subsection 2 is subject to a civil penalty of $500 per day of the violation, and each dayï¿½s continuance of the violation constitutes a separate and distinct violation.

section.heading: Use of likeness, registered trademark or intellectual property of food dispensing establishment without written consent prohibited; civil penalties.

content.p: A food delivery service platform provider shall not use the likeness, registered trademark or intellectual property of a food dispensing establishment unless the food delivery service platform provider first obtains the written consent of the food dispensing establishment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A food delivery service platform provider who violates the provisions of subsection 1 is subject to a civil penalty of $500 per day of the violation, and each dayï¿½s continuance of the violation constitutes a separate and distinct violation.

section.heading: Action for damages for unlawful use of likeness, registered trademark or intellectual property of food dispensing establishment.

content.p: A food dispensing establishment whose likeness, registered trademark or intellectual property was used by a food delivery service platform provider in violation ofNRS 597.7637may bring an action against the food delivery service platform provider in any court of competent jurisdiction and may recover the sum of $5,000 or the amount of actual damages sustained, whichever is greater. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the food dispensing establishment prevails in the action, the court may award such punitive damages and equitable relief as the court determines to be proper.

section.heading: Duty of food delivery service platform provider to disclose to user certain information associated with online food order; manner of disclosure.

content.p: Before an online food order is consummated with a user, the food delivery service platform provider must disclose to the user the following information in plain language and in a conspicuous manner: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The total online food order price; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Each portion of the total online food order price that is attributable to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The food purchase price; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any sales tax or other tax; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any delivery fee or service fee charged to the user by the food delivery service platform provider or food dispensing establishment; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any gratuity to be paid to the person who delivers the food; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A statement that indicates that a commission is to be paid by the food dispensing establishment in connection with the online food order. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If, after the consummation of an online food order, the user is provided with a receipt for the online food order, the information required to be disclosed pursuant to paragraphs
and
of subsection 1 must be set forth on the receipt in plain language and in a conspicuous manner.

section.heading: Food delivery service platform provider may request to disclose required information in alternative manner; submission of request to Commissioner of Consumer Affairs.

content.p: If a food delivery service platform provider determines that it is not feasible to disclose the information required byNRS 597.7639in the manner provided in that section, the provider may submit a request to the Commissioner of Consumer Affairs to disclose the information in an alternative manner. Such a request must include, without limitation, a proposal for an alternative manner in which to disclose the information required byNRS 597.7639and any other information the Commissioner deems necessary. If the Commissioner approves the request, the food delivery service platform provider may disclose the information required byNRS 597.7639in the manner set forth in the approved request.

section.heading: Limitation on commission for online food order during certain periods in which declaration of emergency is in effect; provisions do not supersede or preempt certain ordinances.

content.p: During any period in which a declaration of emergency is in effect in a county in this State and social distancing requirements and occupancy limitations on the capacity of food dispensing establishments apply to that county, a food delivery service platform provider shall not charge a food dispensing establishment in that county a commission for an online food order that exceeds 15 percent of the food purchase price of the online food order, plus a credit card processing fee, if any. A food dispensing establishment in such a county may agree in writing to pay a food delivery service platform provider a commission that exceeds the limit established in this subsection to obtain optional products or services, including, without limitation, advertising, marketing or access to customer subscription programs. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A food delivery service platform provider shall not reduce the compensation rates paid to any person who delivers food for the provider or garnish the gratuities of such a person as a result of this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The provisions of this section do not supersede or preempt an ordinance enacted by a governing body of a county in this State that places limits on the maximum commission that a food delivery service platform provider may charge a food dispensing establishment if such an ordinance was in effect on or before April 30, 2021. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½governing bodyï¿½ means the board of county commissioners or, in the case of Carson City, the Board of Supervisors.

section.heading: Knowing violation deemed deceptive trade practice.

content.p: A person who knowingly violatesNRS 597.7639,597.764or597.7641is deemed to have committed a deceptive trade practice for the purposes ofNRS 598.0903to598.0999, inclusive.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: ï¿½Commercial useï¿½ includes the use of the name, voice, signature, photograph or likeness of a person on or in any product, merchandise or goods or for the purposes of advertising, selling or soliciting the purchase of any product, merchandise, goods or service. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Governmental agencyï¿½ means the Commission on Tourism of the Department of Tourism and Cultural Affairs and a governmental entity in a county whose population is 100,000 or more that has as a statutory purpose, power or duty the promotion of travel or tourism in this state and that employs photographers full-time or by contract to take pictures to promote travel and tourism, portray historical events or commemorate persons or physical sites that are significant in the history of the state. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Personï¿½ means a natural person.

section.heading: Scope.

content.p: The provisions ofNRS 597.770to597.810, inclusive, apply to any commercial use within this state of a living or deceased personï¿½s name, voice, signature, photograph or likeness regardless of the personï¿½s domicile.

section.heading: Existence and term of right; written consent required for commercial use; exceptions.

content.p: There is a right of publicity in the name, voice, signature, photograph or likeness of every person. The right endures for a term consisting of the life of the person and 50 years after his or her death, regardless of whether the person commercially exploits the right during his or her lifetime. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any commercial use by another of the name, voice, signature, photograph or likeness of a person requires the written consent of that person or his or her successor in interest unless: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The use is contained in material which is commercially sponsored but the use is not directly connected with the commercial sponsorship; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The use is an attempt to portray, imitate, simulate or impersonate a person in a play, book, magazine article, newspaper article, musical composition, film, or a radio, television or other audio or visual program, except where the use is directly connected with commercial sponsorship; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The use is in connection with an original work of art except that multiple editions of such a work of art require consent; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The use is in connection with an advertisement or commercial announcement for a use permitted by this subsection; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The use is in connection with the efforts of a governmental agency to promote travel and tourism in this state, portray historical events or commemorate persons or physical sites that are significant in the history of this state, except where the use is directly connected with commercial sponsorship. ï¿½For the purposes of this subsection, the issue of whether a use is directly connected with commercial sponsorship is a question of fact, to be determined by the trier of fact in an action brought pursuant toNRS 597.810. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If a governmental agency intends to have photographs taken at a public event for use pursuant to paragraph

of subsection 2, the governmental agency shall, if practicable, announce or otherwise inform the public, or request the sponsor of the event to announce or otherwise inform the public, that photographs may be taken that can be used in materials for the promotion of travel and tourism in this state without permission from the person photographed.

section.heading: Transferability of right; commercial use upon death; rights of successors in interest; registration of claim; fee.

content.p: The right of publicity established byNRS 597.790is freely transferable, in whole or in part, by contract, license, gift, conveyance, assignment, devise or testamentary trust by a person or his or her successor in interest. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a deceased person has not transferred his or her rights as provided by subsection 1, and he or she has no surviving beneficiary or successor in interest upon his or her death, the commercial use of his or her name, voice, signature, photograph or likeness does not require consent. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A successor in interest or a licensee of a deceased person may file in the Office of the Secretary of State, on a form prescribed by the Secretary of State and upon the payment of a filing fee of $25, a verified application for registration of his or her claim. The application must include: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The date of death of the deceased person; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The name and address of the claimant; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The basis of the claim; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A description of the rights claimed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A successor in interest or a licensee of a deceased person may not assert any right against any unauthorized commercial use of the deceased personï¿½s name, voice, signature, photograph or likeness that begins before the filing of an application to register his or her claim. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A person, firm or corporation seeking to use the name, voice, signature, photograph or likeness of a deceased person for commercial purposes must first make a reasonable effort, in good faith, to discover the identity of any person who qualifies as a successor in interest to the deceased person. A person claiming to be a successor in interest to a deceased person must, within 6 months after the date he or she becomes aware or should reasonably have become aware of an unauthorized commercial use of the deceased personï¿½s name, voice, signature, photograph or likeness, register a claim with the Secretary of State pursuant to subsection 3. Failure to register shall be deemed a waiver of any right of publicity. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Secretary of State may microfilm or reproduce by other techniques any document filed pursuant to this section and thereafter destroy the original of the document. The microfilm or other reproduction is admissible in any court of record. The Secretary of State may destroy the microfilm or other reproduction 50 years after the death of the person whose identity is the subject of the claim. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A claim registered pursuant to this section is a public record.

section.heading: Remedies for unauthorized commercial use; liability of owner or employee of medium used for advertising.

content.p: Any commercial use of the name, voice, signature, photograph or likeness of another by a person, firm or corporation without first having obtained written consent for the use is subject to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Injunctive relief to prevent or restrain the unauthorized use; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An action at law for any injuries sustained by reason of the unauthorized use. In such a suit, the plaintiff may recover: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Actual damages, but not less than $750; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Exemplary or punitive damages, if the trier of fact finds that the defendant knowingly made use of the name, voice, signature, photograph or likeness of another person without the consent required byNRS 597.790. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

No owner or employee of any medium used for advertising is liable pursuant to this section for any unauthorized commercial use of a personï¿½s name, voice, signature, photograph or likeness unless it is established that the owner or employee had actual knowledge of the unauthorized use.

section.heading: ï¿½Device for automatic dialing and announcingï¿½ defined.

content.p: Incorporates a storage capability of telephone numbers to be called and utilizes a random or sequential number generator producing telephone numbers to be called; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Is used exclusively, working alone or in conjunction with other equipment, to disseminate a prerecorded message to the telephone number called to solicit a person at the telephone number called to purchase goods or services.

section.heading: Use prohibited; exceptions; restrictions.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3 andNRS 597.816, a person shall not use a device for automatic dialing and announcing to disseminate a prerecorded message in a telephone call unless, before the message is disseminated, a recorded or unrecorded natural voice: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Informs the person who answers the telephone call of the nature of the call, including, without limitation, the fact that a device for automatic dialing and announcing will be used to disseminate the message if the person who answers the call remains on the line; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Provides to the person who answers the telephone call the name, address and telephone number of the business or organization, if any, being represented by the caller. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person shall not operate a device for automatic dialing and announcing to place: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A call that is received by a telephone located in this State during the period between 8 p.m. and 9 a.m.; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A call-back or second call to the same telephone number if a person at the telephone number terminated the original call. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

This section does not prohibit the use of a device for automatic dialing and announcing to dial the number of and play a recorded message to a person with whom the person using the device or another person affiliated with the person using the device has a preexisting business relationship.

section.heading: Additional exceptions to prohibition of use.

content.p: A school or school district to contact the parents or guardians of a pupil regarding the attendance of the pupil or regarding other business of the school or school district. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A nonprofit organization. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A video service provider that provides cable television or other video services to contact its customers regarding a previously arranged installation of such services at the premises of the customer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A public utility to contact its customers regarding a previously arranged installation of utility services at the premises of the customer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A facility that processes or stores petroleum, volatile petroleum products, natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas, combustible chemicals, explosives, high-level radioactive waste or other dangerous substances to advise local residents, public service agencies and news media of an actual or potential life-threatening emergency. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A state or local governmental agency, or a private entity operating under contract with and at the direction of such an agency, to provide: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Information relating to public safety; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Information relating to a police or fire emergency; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A warning of an impending or threatening emergency. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A candidate for public office, committee advocating the passage or defeat of a ballot question, political party, committee sponsored by a political party or a committee for political action.

section.heading: Penalty.

content.p: A person who violates any provision ofNRS 597.814is guilty of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For a first offense, a misdemeanor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For a second offense, a gross misdemeanor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For a third and any subsequent offense, a category E felony and shall be punished as provided inNRS 193.130. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a person is found guilty or guilty but mentally ill of, or has pleaded guilty, guilty but mentally ill or nolo contendere to, violating any provision ofNRS 597.814, his or her telephone service to which a device for automatic dialing and announcing has been connected must be suspended for a period determined by the court. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In addition to any other penalty, a person who violates any provision ofNRS 597.814is subject to a civil penalty of not more than $10,000 for each violation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A violation of any provision ofNRS 597.814constitutes a deceptive trade practice for the purposes ofNRS 598.0903to598.0999, inclusive.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: As used inNRS 597.8191to597.8198, inclusive, unless the context otherwise requires, the words and terms defined inNRS 597.8192and597.8193have the meanings ascribed to them in those sections.

section.heading: ï¿½Service memberï¿½ defined.

content.p: A member of the active or reserve components of the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps or Coast Guard of the United States who is on active duty; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A member of the Merchant Marine, the Commissioned Corps of the Public Health Service or the Commissioned Corps of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration of the United States; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A member of the National Guard.

section.heading: ï¿½Written noticeï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Written noticeï¿½ includes, without limitation, the provision of notice by electronic mail.

section.heading: Termination or suspension of contracts upon deployment or permanent change of station authorized; proof; effective date.

content.p: A service member may, upon written notice to the service provider, terminate or suspend a contract for a service described in subsection 3 at any time after the date the service member receives military service orders: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For a permanent change of station; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To deploy with a military unit, or as an individual in support of a military operation, for a period of not less than 30 days. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a service member receives military service orders for a permanent change of station, the spouse of the service member may, upon written notice to the service provider, terminate or suspend a contract for a service described in subsection 3 at any time after the date the service member receives the military service orders for a permanent change of station. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of subsections 1 and 2 apply to a contract for any of the following services: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Except as otherwise provided in subsection 6, telecommunication service. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Internet service. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Membership in a health club. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Video service. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The service member or the spouse of a service member must provide written proof to the service provider of the official military service orders showing that the service member has been relocated or deployed, as applicable: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
At the time written notice is given pursuant to subsection 1 or 2; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If precluded by military necessity or circumstances that make the provision of proof at that time unreasonable or impossible, within 90 days after the written notice is given. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A termination or suspension of a contract for services under this section is effective on the date on which written notice is given by the service member or the spouse of a service member, as applicable, pursuant to subsection 1 or 2. The termination or suspension of service does not eliminate or alter any contractual obligation to pay for services rendered before the effective date of the written notice, unless otherwise provided by law. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A service member may terminate a contract for cellular telephone service or telephone exchange service in accordance with the provisions of 50 U.S.C. ï¿½ 3956. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Health clubï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 598.9415. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Telecommunication serviceï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 711.135. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Video serviceï¿½ means the provision of multichannel video programming generally considered comparable to video programming delivered by a television broadcast station, cable service or other digital television service, whether provided as part of a tier, on-demand or on a per channel basis, without regard to the technology used to deliver the video service. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The term includes, without limitation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) Cable service; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) Internet protocol technology or any successor technology. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The term does not include: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) Any video content provided solely as part of, and through, a service that enables users to access content, information, electronic mail or other services that are offered via the public Internet. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) Any wireless multichannel video programming provided by a commercial mobile service provider.

section.heading: Reinstatement of service.

content.p: A service member or the spouse of a service member who terminates or suspends a contract for the provision of a service pursuant toNRS 597.8194may, upon giving written notice to the service provider within 90 days after termination of the service memberï¿½s relocation or deployment, as applicable, reinstate the provision of services: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the service member was relocated or deployed for not more than 12 consecutive months, on the same terms and conditions as originally agreed upon with the service provider before the termination or suspension. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the service member was relocated or deployed for more than 12 consecutive months, on the same terms and conditions that were offered by the service provider to any new customer at the lowest discounted or promotional rate within the 12-month period immediately preceding the termination of the service memberï¿½s relocation or deployment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Upon receipt of the written notice of reinstatement, the service provider must resume the provision of services or, if the services are no longer available, provide substantially similar services within a reasonable time, not exceeding 30 days, from the date of receipt of the written notice of reinstatement.

section.heading: Charges solely for termination, suspension or reinstatement prohibited; period of nonliability for payment.

content.p: Must not be charged a penalty, fee, loss of deposit or any other additional cost because of the termination, suspension or reinstatement; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Is not liable for payment for any services after the effective date of the termination or suspension, and until the effective date of a reinstatement of services pursuant toNRS 597.8195, if applicable.

section.heading: Action for recovery of damages or for declaratory or equitable relief; attorneyï¿½s fees and costs.

content.p: Any person injured by a violation ofNRS 597.8191to597.8198, inclusive, may bring an action for recovery of damages or for declaratory or equitable relief. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In addition to the relief authorized by this section, the court may award reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees and costs to a plaintiff that prevails under this section.

section.heading: Enforcement by Attorney General; remedies.

content.p: Issue a temporary or permanent injunction. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Impose a civil penalty not to exceed: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For a first violation, $25,000; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For any subsequent violation, $50,000. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Issue a declaratory judgment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Order restitution for the service member or the spouse of the service member, as applicable. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Order the payment of attorneyï¿½s fees and costs. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Order such other relief as the court deems just.

section.heading: Profiteering in articles on which there is sales tax; penalty.

content.p: No person, dealer, firm, agency, partnership, corporation, service station, garage, or business concern of any kind, wholesale or retail, shall add to the selling price of any article of merchandise, commodity, service or utility, motor part or accessory, tire, gasoline or other motor fuel or lubricating liquid, or any article whatsoever upon which there is or hereafter may be a sales tax, either federal or state, when sold, offered or exposed for sale, trade or barter in this State, more than the actual amount of such sales tax in the smallest unit under which any of such articles is offered for sale or sold; provided, that where such sales tax in case of units of any such merchandise or articles amounts to less than 1 cent, 1 cent and no more may be added to the price of the unit when sold. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A violation of the provisions of subsection 1 shall be a misdemeanor.

section.heading: Unlawful additions to entertainment or amusement tax; penalty.

content.p: If a federal or state tax is imposed on an admission to or on a ticket sold for a public entertainment or amusement of any kind in this state, it shall be unlawful to add to the price of the admission or ticket more than the actual amount of the tax. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A violation of the provisions of subsection 1 shall be a misdemeanor.

section.heading: Unlawful retention of deposit for longer than agreed time; penalty.

content.p: A person shall not hold a deposit for the purchase of an item longer than the time specified in a contract between the purchaser and the seller if the purchaser is entitled to the return of the deposit. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A person who violates the provisions of subsection 1 shall be punished by a fine of not more than the amount of the deposit multiplied by the number of working days the deposit was retained after return was due.

section.heading: Shoplifting: Merchant may request person on premises to keep merchandise in full view; detention of suspect; immunity of merchant from liability; display of notice.

content.p: As used in this section and inNRS 597.860and597.870: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Merchandiseï¿½ means any personal property, capable of manual delivery, displayed, held or offered for sale by a merchant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Merchantï¿½ means an owner or operator, and the agent, consignee, employee, lessee, or officer of an owner or operator, of any merchantï¿½s premises. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Premisesï¿½ means any establishment or part thereof wherein merchandise is displayed, held or offered for sale. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any merchant may request any person on the merchantï¿½s premises to place or keep in full view any merchandise the person may have removed, or which the merchant has reason to believe the person may have removed, from its place of display or elsewhere, whether for examination, purchase or for any other purpose. No merchant is criminally or civilly liable on account of having made such a request. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
