Any merchant who has reason to believe that merchandise has been wrongfully taken by a person and that the merchant can recover the merchandise by taking the person into custody and detaining the person may, for the purpose of attempting to effect such recovery or for the purpose of informing a peace officer of the circumstances of such detention, take the person into custody and detain the person, on the premises, in a reasonable manner and for a reasonable length of time. A merchant is presumed to have reason to believe that merchandise has been wrongfully taken by a person and that the merchant can recover the merchandise by taking the person into custody and detaining the person if the merchant observed the person concealing merchandise while on the premises. Such taking into custody and detention by a merchant does not render the merchant criminally or civilly liable for false arrest, false imprisonment, slander or unlawful detention unless the taking into custody and detention are unreasonable under all the circumstances. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

No merchant is entitled to the immunity from liability provided for in this section unless there is displayed in a conspicuous place on the merchantï¿½s premises a notice in boldface type clearly legible and in substantially the following form: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Any merchant or his or her agent who has reason to believe that merchandise has been wrongfully taken by a person may detain such person on the premises of the merchant for the purpose of recovering the property or notifying a peace officer. An adult or the parents or legal guardian of a minor, who steals merchandise is civilly liable for its value and additional damages.NRS 597.850,597.860and597.870.

section.heading: Shoplifting: Civil liability of adult who steals merchandise from or damages property on merchantï¿½s premises.

content.p: An adult who steals merchandise from, or damages property on, a merchantï¿½s premises is civilly liable for the retail value of the merchandise or the fair market value of the other property, plus damages of not less than $100 nor more than $250, costs of suit and reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees. An action may be brought even if there has been no criminal conviction for the theft or damage. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An action under this section may be brought as a small claim in a Justice Court if the total amount sought does not exceed the statutory limit for such a claim.

section.heading: Shoplifting: Civil liability of parent or guardian of minor who steals merchandise from or damages property on merchantï¿½s premises.

content.p: The parent or legal guardian, as the case may be, of a minor who steals merchandise from, or damages property on, a merchantï¿½s premises is civilly liable for: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The retail value of the merchandise; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The fair market value of the damaged property, ï¿½plus damages of not less than $100 nor more than $250, costs of suit and reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees. An action may be brought even if there has been no criminal conviction for the theft or damage. Recovery under this section may be had in addition to, and is not limited by, any other provision of law which limits the liability of a parent or legal guardian for the tortious conduct of a minor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An action under this section may be brought as a small claim in a Justice Court if the total amount sought does not exceed the statutory limit for such a claim.

section.heading: Sale and advertising of master keys for motor vehicles limited; penalty.

content.p: As used in this section, ï¿½master motor vehicle key setï¿½ means a key or keys that may be used to operate more than one motor vehicle. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person shall not sell a master motor vehicle key set to any person except automobile dealers, automobile repairers, locksmiths and peace officers of the State of Nevada. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person shall not advertise the sale of a master motor vehicle key set except in trade journals of automobile dealers, automobile repairers and locksmiths. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any person who violates the provisions of subsection 2 or 3 is guilty of a misdemeanor.

section.heading: Advertising that climate of facility for storage of personal property is controlled: Requirements; penalty; civil liability.

content.p: The owner of a facility for the storage of personal property or a person acting on his or her behalf shall not advertise that the facility is ï¿½climate controlledï¿½ unless the advertisement specifies the range of the minimum and maximum temperature and humidity within which the facility is maintained. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If an owner or a person acting on his or her behalf fails to indicate the range of temperature and humidity of a facility in any advertisement that refers to it as being ï¿½climate controlledï¿½ or fails to maintain the temperature and humidity of the facility within the advertised range, the owner is guilty of a misdemeanor and is liable to the occupant for any damages that are caused to the occupantï¿½s personal property as a result of extremes in temperature or humidity, notwithstanding any contrary provision in the rental agreement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

As used in this section, the terms ï¿½facility,ï¿½ ï¿½occupant,ï¿½ ï¿½owner,ï¿½ ï¿½personal propertyï¿½ and ï¿½rental agreementï¿½ have the meanings ascribed to them respectively inNRS 108.4733to108.4748, inclusive.

section.heading: Sale of imitation Indian arts and crafts not clearly labeled as imitation prohibited.

content.p: As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Imitation Indian arts or crafts articlesï¿½ means those made by machine, or made either wholly or partially out of synthetic or artificial materials, or articles which are not made by Indian labor or workmanship. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Indianï¿½ means a person who is enrolled or who is a lineal descendant of one enrolled upon an enrollment listing of the Bureau of Indian Affairs, or upon the enrollment listing of a recognized Indian tribe, domiciled in the United States. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A person shall not distribute, sell or offer for sale in this state any imitation Indian art or craft articles unless the articles are at all times clearly and legibly designated as imitation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Only those articles bearing a registered trademark or label of authentic Indian labor or workmanship may be deemed authentic Indian arts or crafts articles. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any person violating the provisions of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor.

section.heading: Purchase or sale of or possession with intent to sell items made of part or byproduct of certain animals: Prohibition; exceptions; penalties.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, a person shall not purchase, sell, offer for sale or possess with intent to sell any item that is, wholly or partially, made of an animal part or byproduct derived from a shark fin, a lion of the speciesPanthera leoor any species of elephant, rhinoceros, tiger, leopard, cheetah, jaguar, pangolin, sea turtle, ray, mammoth, narwhal, walrus or hippopotamus. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of subsection 1 do not apply to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any activity undertaken by a law enforcement agency or officer pursuant to federal or state law. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An antique that contains a de minimis quantity of an animal part or byproduct derived from any species listed in subsection 1, provided that the animal part or byproduct is a fixed component of the antique and the owner or seller of the antique establishes with documentation evidencing provenance of the antique that the antique is at least 100 years old. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A musical instrument, including, without limitation, piano, string instrument and bow, wind instrument and percussion instrument, that contains a de minimis quantity of an animal part or byproduct derived from any species listed in subsection 1, provided that the owner or seller of the musical instrument: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Possesses any certification or permit required by federal law for the sale of the musical instrument; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Establishes with documentation evidencing provenance that the musical instrument was legally acquired. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A knife or firearm, or a component thereof, that contains an animal part or byproduct derived from any species listed in subsection 1 if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The animal part or byproduct: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) Is a fixed or integral part of the knife or firearm, or the component thereof; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) Originated in or was legally imported to the United States; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The owner or seller of the knife or firearm, or the component thereof, establishes with documentation evidencing provenance that the knife or firearm, or the component thereof, was legally acquired; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
All the requirements for the sale of the knife or firearm, or the component thereof, set forth in federal and state law are met. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Sales authorized by the Department of Business and Industry to a bona fide scientific or educational institution of an item that contains an animal part or byproduct derived from any species listed in subsection 1, provided that the owner or seller of the item: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Possesses any certification or permit required by federal law for the sale of the item; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Establishes with documentation evidencing provenance that the item was legally acquired. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any item that contains an animal part or byproduct derived from any species listed in subsection 1 for which the owner or seller has obtained any certification or permit required by federal law for the sale of the item or that is specifically authorized for sale by federal law, provided that all the requirements for the sale of the item set forth in federal or state law have been met. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any sport-hunted item that is legally obtained in accordance with federal law. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any person who violates a provision of subsection 1: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the second offense, is guilty of a category E felony and shall be punished as provided inNRS 193.130; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the third and any subsequent offense, is guilty of a category D felony and shall be punished as provided inNRS 193.130. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In addition to the criminal penalties set forth in this section, a person who violates a provision of this section, upon conviction, shall pay a civil penalty not to exceed $6,500 or an amount equal to four times the fair market value of the item which is the subject of the violation, whichever is greater. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½De minimis quantityï¿½ means: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Less than 200 grams in weight when examined as a separate component; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Less than 20 percent of the fair market value of an item or of the actual price paid for the item, whichever is greater. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Saleï¿½ or ï¿½sellï¿½ means any act of selling, trading or bartering, for monetary or nonmonetary consideration, and includes any transfer of ownership that occurs in the course of a commercial transaction, but does not include a nonmonetary transfer of ownership to a legal beneficiary of a trust or to a person by way of gift, donation, inheritance or bequest. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Shark finï¿½ means the fresh and uncooked, or cooked, frozen, dried or otherwise processed, detached fin or tail of a shark.

section.heading: Informal merchants: Prohibited acts; penalty; evidence of legal acquisition of new product.

content.p: An informal merchant shall not offer for sale or knowingly allow the sale of any new product that he or she knows or reasonably should have known is stolen, has been recalled by the manufacturer, has been adulterated, has not been maintained at the proper temperature, has an expiration date that has passed, has been discarded by the manufacturer or a retailer, is an inferior product if he or she does not clearly indicate such inferiority, or has any other defect that makes the product ineffective for the use for which it is purchased or that makes the product below the quality expected by the consumer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An informal merchant who violates the provisions of subsection 1 shall be punished: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the sale of the product does not cause substantial bodily harm to another person, for a gross misdemeanor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the sale of the product causes substantial bodily harm to another person, for a category C felony as provided inNRS 193.130. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Upon request of a peace officer, an informal merchant shall provide reliable evidence of the legal acquisition of a new product that the merchant is offering for sale. If it is determined that the product was stolen and the informal merchant fails to provide such evidence, an inference is created that the informal merchant knew or should have known that the product was stolen. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Informal marketï¿½ means: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A gathering at which: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) Two or more persons offer personal property for sale or exchange; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) A fee is charged for the sale or exchange of personal property; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (III) A fee is charged for admission to the area in which personal property is offered for sale or exchange; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A place at which personal property is offered or displayed for sale or exchange on more than six occasions in a period of 12 months, ï¿½whether held in a building, under cover or in the open air. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Informal merchantï¿½ means a person who does not have an established retail store in the county and who transports an inventory of goods to an informal market and displays the goods for sale, offers them for sale at retail or sells them at retail. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½New productï¿½ means any tangible good which has never been used or which is in its original, unopened package or container. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Stolenï¿½ means taken unlawfully from or without the permission of the owner, whether or not the person who took the item is or has been prosecuted or convicted for the taking of the item.

section.heading: Acceptance of permanent resident card to identify customer.

content.p: If a business accepts a driverï¿½s license or identification card issued by the Department of Motor Vehicles for the purpose of identifying a customer, the business shall not refuse to accept a permanent resident card for the same purpose. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½permanent resident cardï¿½ means a Permanent Resident Card issued by the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services of the Department of Homeland Security.

section.heading: Acceptance of tribal identification card to identify customer.

content.p: If a business accepts a driverï¿½s license or identification card issued by the Department of Motor Vehicles for the purpose of identifying a customer, the business shall not refuse to accept a tribal identification card for the same purpose unless the business reasonably determines that a federal law or regulation requires the use of a different form of identification. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½tribal identification cardï¿½ means an identification card issued by a tribal government which satisfies the requirements of subsection 3 ofNRS 232.006.

section.heading: Restrictions on recording of account number of credit card as condition to accepting check or draft; restrictions on recording of telephone number as condition to accepting credit card.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, a business shall not, without the customerï¿½s consent, record the account number of any of a customerï¿½s credit cards on the customerï¿½s check or draft as a condition of accepting that check or draft. This subsection does not prohibit: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The business from requiring the customer to produce reasonable forms of positive identification other than a credit card, including, without limitation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A driverï¿½s license; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A permanent resident card; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A tribal identification card; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A consular identification card, ï¿½as a condition of accepting a check or draft. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The business from requesting the customer to display a credit card as an indicia of creditworthiness or financial responsibility, if the only information recorded by the business concerning the credit card is the type of credit card displayed, the issuer of the card and the date the card expires. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The business from requesting the customer to record the account number of his or her credit card on the check or draft with which payment on the credit card account is being made. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The business from requesting the production of or recording of the account number of a credit card as a condition of cashing a check or draft if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The business has agreed with the issuer of the credit card to cash the checks or drafts as a service to the cardholders of the issuer; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The issuer has agreed to guarantee any such check or draft so cashed; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The cardholder has given actual, apparent or implied authority for the use of his or her account number for this purpose. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, a business shall not, without the customerï¿½s consent, record a customerï¿½s telephone number on the credit card sales slip as a condition of accepting his or her credit card. This subsection does not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Prohibit the recordation of personal identifying information required for a special purpose incidental to the use of the credit card, such as the delivery, shipping, servicing or installation of the purchased merchandise. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Apply to a transaction in which the customer receives a cash advance against his or her credit card or to a transaction involving the use of preprinted spaces for personal identifying information that the business accepting the credit card has a contractual obligation to record in order to complete the transaction. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Apply to a transaction in which the customerï¿½s purchase is made by the use of a device that electronically authorizes the use of the credit card and processes information relating thereto. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, unless the context otherwise requires: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Consular identification cardï¿½ means an identification card issued by a consulate of a foreign government, which consulate is located within the State of Nevada. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Credit cardï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 205.630. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Identification card issued by the Department of Motor Vehiclesï¿½ means an identification card of the type described inNRS 483.810to483.890, inclusive. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Permanent resident cardï¿½ means a Permanent Resident Card issued by the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services of the Department of Homeland Security. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Tribal identification cardï¿½ means an identification card issued by a tribal government which satisfies the requirements of subsection 3 ofNRS 232.006.

section.heading: Restrictions on printing expiration date or account number of credit card or debit card on receipt: Restrictions applicable to businesses which accept credit cards or debit cards; penalties; enforcement.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in this section, if a business accepts credit cards or debit cards for the transaction of business, the business shall not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Print more than the last five digits of the account number of the credit card or debit card on any receipt provided to the cardholder; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Print more than the last five digits of the account number of the credit card or debit card on any copy of a receipt retained by the business. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Applies only to receipts that are electronically printed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Does not apply to transactions in which the only means of recording the credit card or debit card number is: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
By handwriting the credit card or debit card number; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
By imprinting or copying the credit card or debit card. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A business that violates any provision of this section is liable for a civil penalty in the amount of $500. The business must be given notice of the violation and 2 weeks to correct the violation. A business that does not correct the violation within 2 weeks after receiving notice of the violation is liable for an additional civil penalty in the amount of $1,000 per week until the business corrects the violation, except that the aggregate amount of civil penalties imposed on a business for violations which occur on the same premises must not exceed $4,500. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A civil penalty imposed pursuant to subsection 3 must be recovered in a civil action brought in the name of the State of Nevada by the Attorney General or by any district attorney in a court of competent jurisdiction. Any penalty collected pursuant to this section must be paid to the State Treasurer for credit to the State General Fund. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Attorney General or the district attorney may bring an action in any court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the State of Nevada against any business to restrain and prevent any violation of this section. The court may issue an injunction for those purposes without proof of actual damage sustained by any person. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A business that violates any order or injunction issued pursuant to this section is guilty of a gross misdemeanor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Credit cardï¿½ means any instrument or device, whether known as a credit card, credit plate or by any other name, issued with or without fee by an issuer for the use of the cardholder in obtaining money, property, goods, services or anything else of value on credit. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Debit cardï¿½ means any instrument or device, whether known as a debit card or by any other name, that is issued with or without a fee by an issuer for the use of the cardholder in obtaining money, property, goods, services or anything else of value, subject to the issuer removing money from the checking account or savings account of the cardholder.

section.heading: Restrictions on printing expiration date or account number of credit card or debit card on receipt: Restrictions applicable to manufacturer or supplier of device; penalty; enforcement.

content.p: A manufacturer or supplier of a cash register or other machine or device that prints receipts for transactions in which a credit card or debit card is used shall not provide, lease or sell for the transaction of business any equipment that does not allow a business to comply with the provisions of subsection 1 ofNRS 597.945. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Attorney General or the district attorney may bring an action in any court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the State of Nevada against any person to restrain and prevent any violation of this section. The court may issue an injunction for those purposes without proof of actual damage sustained by any person. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who violates any order or injunction issued pursuant to this section is guilty of a gross misdemeanor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Credit cardï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 597.945. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Debit cardï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 597.945. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Supplierï¿½ means a person engaged in the business of providing, leasing or selling cash registers or other machines or devices that are used to print receipts in the transaction of business.

section.heading: Unsolicited merchandise deemed unconditional gift to recipient; liability of sender; exceptions.

content.p: Any person who receives unsolicited goods, wares or merchandise offered for sale, but not actually ordered or requested by him or her orally or in writing, is entitled to consider those goods, wares or merchandise an unconditional gift, and may use or dispose of them as he or she sees fit without obligation on his or her part to the sender. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The sender of unsolicited goods, wares or merchandise must pay actual and reasonable expenses incurred by the recipient: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In returning the goods, wares or merchandise to the sender; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In resisting attempts by the sender to collect payment for the goods, wares or merchandise. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The sender of unsolicited goods, wares or merchandise is liable to the recipient for any impairment of the credit of the recipient caused by attempts by the sender to collect payment for the goods, wares or merchandise. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of subsections 1, 2 and 3 do not apply to the following: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Where delivery of goods, wares or merchandise is by mistake in response to an order to the sender for other goods, wares or merchandise. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Where delivery is made by mistake to someone other than a person who ordered goods, wares or merchandise from the sender. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Where the sender has sent a substitute or substitutes in response to an order for certain goods, wares or merchandise. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Where someone has ordered a gift for another from the sender, and the goods, wares or merchandise were sent directly to the recipient of the gift. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Where delivery of goods, wares or merchandise is made by mistake to a member of a subscription-type plan (such as a book club or record club) operated by the sender.

section.heading: Collection of fee for dishonored check accepted as payment for goods or services.

content.p: A seller, or his or her agent, may collect a fee of not more than $25 for each check which was accepted by the seller as payment for goods or services and, upon presentment to the drawee, was not honored because the drawer stopped payment on the check, the drawer does not have an account with the drawee or the drawer does not have sufficient funds in his or her account or credit with the drawee to cover the amount of the check. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Checkï¿½ includes a draft or other negotiable order for the payment of money on demand which is drawn on a bank or other financial institution. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Draweeï¿½ means the person ordered in the check to make payment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Drawerï¿½ means the person who signs or is identified in the check as the person ordering payment.

section.heading: Sale of novelty lighter prohibited; applicability; penalty; enforcement.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, a person may not sell at retail, offer for retail sale or distribute for retail sale or promotion in this State a novelty lighter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

This section does not apply to the transportation of novelty lighters through this State or the storage of novelty lighters in a warehouse or distribution center in this State that is closed to the public for purposes of retail sales. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Attorney General or any district attorney, on the request of the State Fire Marshal or on his or her own motion, may bring an action in any court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the State of Nevada to enjoin a violation of this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500. No sentence of incarceration may be imposed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½novelty lighterï¿½: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Means a mechanical or electrical device which is typically used for lighting cigarettes, cigars or pipes that may operate on any fuel, including, without limitation, butane, isobutene or liquid fuel, and which: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Is designed to resemble and reasonably does resemble a cartoon character, toy, gun, watch, musical instrument, vehicle, animal, food, beverage or other similar article that does not resemble a standard disposable lighter; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Plays musical notes, has flashing lights or has more than one button or function; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Does not include: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any mechanical or electrical device primarily used to ignite fuel for fireplaces or for charcoal or gas grills; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Standard disposable lighters that are printed or decorated, including, without limitation, through the use of a heat shrinkable sleeve, with logos, labels, decals or artwork.

section.heading: Knowing manufacture, sale or distribution of certain products containing Bisphenol A prohibited.

content.p: A person shall not knowingly manufacture, sell or distribute in this State any bottle or cup which contains intentionally added Bisphenol A if the bottle or cup is designed or intended to be filled with any liquid or food intended primarily for consumption directly from the bottle or cup by a child who is less than 4 years of age.

section.heading: Knowing manufacture, sale or distribution of baby food or infant formula in container containing Bisphenol A prohibited.

content.p: A person shall not knowingly manufacture, sell or distribute in this State any baby food or infant formula stored in a container which contains intentionally added Bisphenol A. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Baby foodï¿½ means any prepared solid food consisting of a soft paste or is otherwise easily chewed and is intended primarily for consumption by a child who is less than 4 years of age and is commercially available. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Containerï¿½ means any receptacle, including, without limitation, a box, can, jar, or a lid, that comes in direct physical contact with baby food or infant formula. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Infant formulaï¿½ means any liquid or powder that purports or is represented to be for special dietary use solely as a food for infants by nature of its simulation of human milk or its suitability as a complete or partial substitute for human milk.

section.heading: Limitations on agreements which include provision requiring arbitration of disputes arising between parties.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, an agreement which includes a provision which requires a person to submit to arbitration any dispute arising between the parties to the agreement must include specific authorization for the provision which indicates that the person has affirmatively agreed to the provision. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If an agreement includes a provision which requires a person to submit to arbitration any dispute arising between the parties to the agreement and the agreement fails to include the specific authorization required pursuant to subsection 1, the provision is void and unenforceable. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The provisions of this section do not apply to an agreement that is a collective bargaining agreement. As used in this subsection, ï¿½collective bargainingï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 288.032. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of this section do not apply to a provision in a will or trust instrument that requires the arbitration of disputes which is enforceable pursuant toNRS 164.930.

section.heading: Prohibited provisions relating to review, comment or statement by consumer in form contract for purchase, lease or rental of consumer goods or services; penalties; enforcement.

content.p: A seller or lessor of consumer goods or services shall not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Include in any form contract or proposed form contract with a consumer for the purchase, lease or rental of consumer goods or services any provision that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Limits or requires the consumer to waive his or her rights to provide a review, comment or other statement concerning the consumer goods or services or the seller or lessor; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Imposes a penalty on the consumer for providing such a review, comment or other statement; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Declares that the provision of such a review, comment or other statement by the consumer is a breach of the form contract; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Enforce or threaten to enforce a provision described in paragraph
; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Refuse or threaten to refuse to enter into a form contract with a consumer solely because the consumer does not agree to the inclusion in the form contract of a provision described in paragraph
. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any provision that is included in a form contract with a consumer for the purchase, lease or rental of consumer goods or services in violation of subsection 1, with or without consideration, is against public policy and is void and unenforceable. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any person who violates subsection 1 is guilty of a misdemeanor and, in addition to any criminal penalty, is liable for: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A civil penalty of not more than: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the first violation, $2,500; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the second or subsequent violation, $5,000 for each violation; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the court finds that the violation is reckless, willful or wanton, $10,000, in addition to the civil penalty set forth in subparagraph
or
; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The costs incurred to recover the civil penalty, including, without limitation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Reasonable costs specified inNRS 18.005; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An action to recover the civil penalty may be brought by the consumer, the Attorney General or a district attorney or city attorney, as appropriate. The action may be instituted in any court of competent jurisdiction in the city or county in which either party resides, the defendant can be found or in which the violation occurred. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any money awarded by a court pursuant to this section must be awarded to the person or governmental entity that brought the action. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The civil remedy provided by this section is in addition to, and not exclusive of, any other available remedy or penalty. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

This section does not prohibit a person who maintains an online forum, including, without limitation, an Internet website, from removing from the forum any statement that the person is lawfully entitled to remove. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Nothing in this section shall be construed as affecting: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any civil cause of action for defamation, libel, slander or any similar cause of action. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Consumerï¿½ means a natural person. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Consumer goods or servicesï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 598.170. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Form contractï¿½ means a contract or agreement with standardized terms that is: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Used by a seller or lessor in the course of selling, leasing or renting consumer goods or services of the seller or lessor; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Imposed on a consumer without a meaningful opportunity for the consumer to negotiate the standardized terms. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Lessorï¿½ means a lessor and any agent or employee of the lessor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Sellerï¿½ means a seller and any agent or employee of the seller.

section.heading: Prohibition on certain offers to lease living animal or goods intended for personal, family or household use; federal Truth in Lending Act applicable to retail installment contract for sale of living animal or goods intended for personal, family or household use; failure to comply constitutes deceptive trade practice; violation constitutes consumer fraud.

content.p: A person shall not offer to lease any living animal or goods intended for personal, family or household use, including, without limitation, pets, tires, batteries and hearing aids, if the living animal or good is expected to have not more than a de minimis residual financial value at the end of the term of the lease or contract. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any retail installment contract for the sale of any living animal or goods intended for personal, family or household use, including, without limitation, pets, tires, batteries and hearing aids, is subject to the provisions of the Truth in Lending Act, 15 U.S.C. ï¿½ï¿½ 1601 et seq., and any regulations adopted pursuant thereto. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The failure of a person to comply with this section constitutes a deceptive trade practice for the purposes ofNRS 598.0903to598.0999, inclusive. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A violation of this section constitutes consumer fraud for the purposes ofNRS 41.600. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of this section do not apply to any lease or contract on furniture or household electronics. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Goodsï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 104.2105. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Household electronicsï¿½ means electronic devices, personal effects and property of an electronic nature used or to be used in a dwelling. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Residual financial valueï¿½ means the amount the living animal or good is worth at the end of the term of the lease or contract and includes, without limitation, the salvage value of the living animal or good. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Retail installment contractï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 97.105. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Salvage valueï¿½ means the amount expected to be obtained when the living animal or good is disposed of at the end of its useful life.

section.heading: Prohibited acts relating to sale, preparation, distribution or advertisement of kratom products or products containing kratom.

content.p: A person shall not knowingly sell or offer to sell any material, compound, mixture or preparation containing a kratom product to a child under the age of 18 years. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A person shall not knowingly prepare, distribute, advertise, sell or offer to sell a kratom product that is adulterated with a substance that affects the quality or strength of the kratom product to such a degree as to render the kratom product injurious to a consumer. A person has not violated the provisions of this subsection if he or she can show by a preponderance of evidence that he or she relied in good faith upon the representations of a manufacturer, processor, packer or distributor of the kratom product. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person shall not sell a kratom product that does not have a label that clearly sets forth the ingredients and directions for the safe and effective use of the kratom product. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who violates any provision of this section is subject to a civil penalty of not more than $1,000 for each violation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½kratom productï¿½ means any product or ingredient containing: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any part of the leaf of theMitragyna Speciosaplant if the plant contains the alkaloid mitragynine or 7-hydroxymitragynine; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A synthetic material that contains the alkaloid mitragynine or 7-hydroxymitragynine, ï¿½regardless of whether the product or ingredient is labeled or sold for human consumption.
